cemeteries and of all moneys received as service charges or rental fees for use of the city park facilities or equipment the parks superintendent shall file all certificates and permits relating to the parks department with the city clerk   prior code    reconveyance or transfer of ownership of burial spaces no person institution association or corporation being the owner of a burial spaces in any cemetery owned by the city shall sell or convey the same to any other person institution association or corporation except 1 after the lawful owner of the cemetery spaces surrenders all original deeds to the city clerk  or 2 to the city for a purchase price set by the council and paid to the city for the same  or 3 after making application for transfer of burial spaces at the city clerks office and paying the transfer of ownership fee ownership is not transferable without approval of the city clerk payment of all appropriate fees and the reissuance of a new certificate of ownership or deed to the new owner or 4 transfer of ownership may be effected by will or intestacy as provided for in colorado revised statutes any transfer of ownership by will or applicable laws of intestacy shall be reported to the city clerk with proof thereof and appropriate transfer fee paid all changes in address of owners of grave spaces should be reported to the city clerk     prior code    abandoned burial spaces a reversion the ownership or right in or to any unoccupied cemetery burial space shall upon abandonment revert to the city of caon city b presumption failure to inter in any burial spaces after one hundred years from purchase transfer or interment in adjacent spaces commonly owned whichever is the later in time shall create and establish a presumption that the same has been abandoned  except that this presumption shall not apply when a letter of intent is filed by the owner or heir in title with the city clerk stating that heshe intends to keep specified spaces vacant c notice required abandonment shall not be deemed complete unless the registered owners or their heirs or assigns shall be notified in writing by certified mail mailed to the last known or registered address by the city clerk in the event that the address of the owner or his heirs cannot be ascertained then notice of such abandonment shall be published two times in the citys official newspaper at least once a week d failure to reply if the registered owner or his heirs or assigns fail to inform the city clerk within sixty days after receipt of notice of abandonment or sixty days after final publication of such notice of intention to retain the burial spaces remaining then abandonment shall become final and the city may thereafter sell transfer and convey title thereto funds derived from any sale of abandoned space shall be deposited in their entirety into the perpetual care fund  protection of paleontological resources  definitions a for the purposes of this chapter 1 collection means a specimen and the associated records documenting the specimen and its recovery 2 critical paleontological resources mean vertebrate fossils and other exceptional fossils that are designated as paleontological landmarks 3 curation means a management and care of collections according to standard professional museum practice which may include inventorying accessing labeling cataloging identifying evaluating documenting storing maintaining periodically inspecting cleaning stabilizing conserving exhibiting exchanging or otherwise disposing of original collections or reproductions  and b providing access to and facilities for studying collections 4 curation facility means the museum or an accredited facility meeting federal curation standards that is designated by the museum memorandum of agreement 5 excavate means the recovery of critical paleontological resources 6 museum means the dinosaur depot museum andor any other curation facility operated by the garden park paleontology society 7 paleontological resources mean remains of prehistoric life 8 permit means a permit for paleontological investigations excavations andor collections of critical paleontological resources on cityowned lands required and issued pursuant to the provisions of this  repository means an accredited facility meeting federal curation standards 10 site means any paleontological deposit or other location that is the source of a specimen 11 specimen means remains of a critical paleontological nature found on or below the surface of the earth   permit required to excavate critical paleontological resources on lands owned or managed by the city of caon cityremoval of specimen or site a before excavating for critical paleontological resources on lands owned by the city of caon city a person must obtain a permit from the city or its designee b application for a permit shall be made on a form approved by resolution of city council and furnished by the city or its designee c the city council may by resolution make rules for the issuance of permits specifying or requiring 1 the minimum permittee qualifications  2 the duration of the permit  3 research designs that provide for the maximum recovery of scientific paleontological and educational information in addition to the physical recovery of specimens and the reporting of paleontological information meeting current standards of scientific rigor  4 the need if any to submit data obtained in the course of field investigation to the city or its designee  5 proof of consultation with a designated museum representative regarding curation of collections  and 6 other information the city or its designee considers necessary d all paleontological work requiring a permit shall be carried out under the supervision of the permittee e no person shall remove from cityowned property any specimen site or portion of a specimen or site without permission from the city f unless otherwise agreed in writing by the city no specimen site or portion of a specimen or site shall be removed to any place other than the museum or a repository or curation facility designated or approved by the city   policies concerning curation and the selection of curation facilities a from time to time city council shall adopt by resolution policies to ensure the adequate curation of all collections from lands owned by the city of caon city it is anticipated that most such policies will be recommended by the garden park paleontology society such policies shall 1 conform to but not limited by federal curation policy  and 2 recognize that if at its discretion the curation facility makes and sells reproductions derived from collections found on lands owned by the city of caon city any revenues after recovering the cost of preparation for sale and a reasonable fee for handling the sale shall be remitted to the city of caon city b subject to the approval of city council by resolution the museum may enter into memoranda of agreement with other repositories to act as its designee for the curation of collections and may at its discretion delegate some or all of its authority to curate c from time to time city council shall adopt by resolution policies and procedures for the selection of curation facilities authorized to curate critical paleontological resources discovered on land owned by the city it is anticipated that most such policies will be recommended by the garden park paleontology society such policies shall consider 1 whether the permittee is a curation facility  2 the proximity of the curation facility or repository to the point of origin of the collection  3 the nature of the collection and the repositorys or curation facilitys ability and desire to curate the collection in question and ability to maximize the scientific and educational benefits for the people of the city  and 4 selection of a second curation facility or repository if the original curation facility or repository becomes unable to curate the collections under its care   curation and deposit of specimen all collections recovered from lands owned by the city of caon city shall be deposited at the museum or at a curation facility or repository approved by the city within a reasonable time after completion of field work   loaning of specimen a the museum andor a repository or curation facility that has accepted a collection removed from cityowned property pursuant to the provisions of this chapter may make specimens available to museums and research institutions when in the opinion of the repository or curation facility 1 the use of the specimens is appropriate  and 2 arrangements are made for safe custodianship of the specimens   paleontological landmarks a sites of significance or sites with exceptional fossils may be recommended to and approved by the city of caon city by resolution as paleontological landmarks b no person without a valid permit issued pursuant to the provisions of this chapter shall conduct paleontological investigations andor excavations on any site designated as a paleontological landmark c privatelyowned sites within the city also may be designated as paleontological landmarks pursuant to written agreement between the landowner and the city all such agreements shall provide that the site described in the agreement shall be treated as land owned by the city for purposes of the applicability and enforcement of this chapter d no person may conduct paleontological investigations andor excavations on a privatelyowned designated landmark without a valid permit from the city and written permission from the owner of the land so designated   fossil collection sites a the city may identify and designate fossil collection sites on lands owned by the city of caon city where it is appropriate to encourage the collection of fossils by individuals families or school groups for educational purposes no permit shall be required with respect to paleontological investigations at such sites fossils other than specimens may be removed from such fossil collection sites and be kept by the individuals groups or institutions that removed them b designated fossil collection sites shall not include critical paleontological resources or paleontological landmarks c designated fossil collection sites shall be interpreted with appropriate signage   unlawful acts and penalties for violations a it is unlawful for any person to excavate critical paleontological resources on lands owned by the city of caon city without first having obtained a valid permit issued pursuant to the provisions of this chapter b it is unlawful for any person to remove critical paleontological resources from land owned by the city of caon city without first having obtained a valid permit issued pursuant to the provisions of this chapter c it is unlawful for any person holding a valid permit issued pursuant to the provisions of this chapter to excavate for remove deposit or dispose of critical paleontological resources on or from lands owned by the city of caon city in a manner prohibited by the other provisions of this chapter or in violation of any requirement or limitation set forth in the permit issued to such person d it is unlawful for any person to violate the provisions of subsections a d e or f e it is unlawful for any person to violate the provisions of f excavations on lands owned by the city that have been designated paleontological landmarks pursuant to be presumed to be excavations for critical paleontological resources and any specimens removed from such paleontological landmarks shall be presumed to be critical paleontological resources g any person who violates any provision of this is guilty of a misdemeanor and upon conviction thereof shall be punished by a fine in an amount that does not exceed the maximum fine provided for in h in addition to any fine or jail sentence imposed the municipal court may order any person convicted of removing critical paleontological resources from lands owned by the city to deliver such resources to the museum or some other repository or curation facility designated by the city the failure of any convicted defendant to abide by any such order within the time provided by the municipal court shall be a violation of this chapter for which such person may be charged and if convicted punished as provided in of this section    librarymuseum advisory board  establishment and operation a the caon city public library is the official library of the city of caon city it was established and is operated and maintained pursuant to of the charter of caon city all references to the library in this are to the caon city public library b the royal gorge regional museum and history center is the official museum of the city of caon city it also was established and is operated and maintained pursuant to of the charter of caon city all references to the museum in this are to the royal gorge regional museum and history center c while it is and will remain the intention of council for the city to continue having both a library and a museum council has also determined that it would be prudent and proper for the library and the museum to share certain cityowned structures and facilities and for the daytoday operations and administrative functions of the library and the museum to be handled by a single administrative department of the city and for city officials to receive advice from a single citizens advisory board the librarymuseum advisory board created under be such single unified advisory board unless the context clearly indicates otherwise all references to board in this are to such librarymuseum advisory board   librarymuseum advisory board created the librarymuseum advisory board shall be comprised of seven 7 members appointed in accordance with the provisions of this such board shall be nonpolitical shall advise the city and its officials on matters concerning the library and the museum and shall have such powers duties responsibilities and functions as are set forth in this the boards primary focus shall be on matters of policy and planning for the library and museum       appointment of members and their terms a the city council shall appoint all members to the board b terms of board members generally shall be three 3 years but council shall appoint some new members to shorter initial terms to achieve the staggered term structure required under of this section c the terms of board members shall be staggered so that the terms of no more than four 4 members will expire in any single calendar year d all board members shall serve without compensation   qualifications applicants for positions on the board shall be persons over the age of eighteen 18 years who reside within or near the boundaries of the city and have a sincere interest in both library and museum operations and policies   applications the existing members of the board shall receive and review all applications from qualified persons seeking appointment to the board to fill new positions and vacancies existing on and after  when membership on the board is increased as provided for in such members shall thereafter interview all qualified applicants and make written recommendations to city council for the appointment of members in numbers sufficient to fill all then existing vacancies thereafter from time to time as new vacancies occur on the board the board will receive and review applications interview applicants and make its written recommendations to the city council the board is hereby authorized to adopt a formal process that is not inconsistent with the provisions of this chapter for interviewing evaluating and making recommendations with respect to the filling of new positions and other vacancies on the board   removal city council at its sole discretion shall have the authority to remove any board member with or without cause prior to the expiration of his or her term   filling vacancies a city council shall fill all vacancies on the initial board and any vacancy thereafter occurring in the membership of the board by appointment of persons who are qualified as provided in who have participated in the interview and evaluation process provided for in city council shall give great weight to the boards recommendations b with respect to the filling of vacancies on the board councils priority for appointment should be qualified applicants who now serve or previously served as officers of local organizations and associations supporting the library andor the museum c whenever a successor is appointed to fill a vacancy created by the resignation or removal of a member prior to the expiration of that members term such successor shall serve out the balance of the unexpired term of the member he or she replaces     meetingofficers the board shall hold regular meetings as established by the board but not less than one meeting per quarter and may hold special meetings as it may from time to time determine to be necessary  provided that all such meetings shall comply with the open meeting requirements set forth in crs et seq on an annual basis the board shall elect from its membership a chairperson vice chairperson and a secretary the chairperson shall preside over all meetings of the board and function as the primary liaison between the board and the city administrator or designee the vice chairperson shall act during the absence of the chairperson the secretary shall keep accurate minutes of board meetings and other board proceedings provide adequate notice of regular and special meetings to all board members and the city administrator or designee and perform such other and similar functions as are assigned by the chairperson     quorum needed to act a majority of the members then in office shall constitute a quorum for the transaction of business at any meeting of the board no action taken or attempted in the absence of a quorum shall be valid except that a meeting may be called to order to determine whether a quorum is present and be adjourned if a quorum is not present     powers and duties the board shall have the following powers a the board shall advise the city administrator and the city council on matters associated with the operation of both the library and museum with the primary focus of its recommendations being on the formulation implementation evaluation and when appropriate modification of policy and practices of both operations b the board shall receive and review complaints and comments concerning the operation management and use of the library and museum and shall promptly forward such complaints comments and its summaries reports and recommendations if any to the city administrator for consideration c the board shall establish in writing subject to approval by city council a formal procedure by which complaints objections and comments from citizensconcerning the type content and display of materials collections and exhibits available to the publicare received and reviewed with an emphasis on better serving the public and enhancing the services of the library and the museum d the board shall make a written annual report to the city council not later than july 31st of each year in which the board shall 1 assess the strengths and weaknesses of the library and museums service to the community  2 make recommendations on short and longterm goals that it believes will improve service  3 make prioritized recommendations on capital improvements it believes are needed to improve the library and museum  and 4 recommend such other policies programs procedures andor guidelines which the board believes will enhance the operation of the library and museum if adopted e the board shall assist the city administrator andor the city council with respect to library and museumrelated issues on a casebycase basis but only when requested to do so by the city administrator andor city council  f the board shall make recommendations concerning any proposed budget for the library and museum g the board shall assist if requested by the city administrator in the selection process for screening of applicants for various professional positions within the library and museum staff h the board will coordinate with the leadership of other citizen groups and associations whose members are interested in and supportive of the functions and operations of the library the museum or both with a view toward encouraging and enlarging their interest and support and when appropriate raising funds for the library and museum   limitations of powers a all budgetary powers expenditures and revenues of and with respect to the library and museum shall be exclusively controlled by the city council and its designees b all personnel matters including but not limited to hiring promotion demotion discipline and termination shall be exclusively controlled by the city administrator in accordance with the provisions of applicable law and city policy c except as may be specifically provided otherwise in this chapter all actions of the board will be advisory in nature the board may exercise advisory functions by making recommendations to the city administrator who shall forward such recommendations to city council when and if council action is necessary or desirable with respect to any matter covered by the boards recommendations nothing in this chapter shall authorize the board or any of its members to exercise any supervisory or other direct control over any employee of the library or museum or to exercise any direct control over the expenditure of funds of the library or museum   legal advisor personnel manager and funds custodian a the city attorney shall be the legal advisor of the board and shall render all legal services required by the board  provided that the performance of such legal services must first be authorized by the city council or by the city administrator b the city administrator or designee shall act as an exofficio member of the board the city administrator or designee shall receive notice of and shall attend all regularly scheduled and special board meetings and shall make him or herself reasonably available to the board and its chairperson for purposes of consultation and advisement concerning the implementation of any policy of the city of caon city the city administrator or designee shall not have a vote on any matter being considered by the board c the director of finance shall act as the legal custodian for any funds generated of the library and museum the accounts of the library and museum shall annually be audited by a certified public accountant selected or approved by the city council and may be audited as a part of the citys annual audit   personnel all personnel of the library and museum shall be subject to the terms and provisions of the personnel policy adopted andor amended from time to time by the city council the city administrator or designee shall have sole and exclusive authority over all said employees   operating manager the city administrator or designee shall be the operating manager of the library and museum and all related facilities with the powers duties and responsibilities given him or her by the charter ordinances regulations and rules of the city of caon city  administrative departments  city administrator to establish other departmentscouncil shall have supervision and control of the department he heads  prohibited gifts to city officials  definitions as used in this chapter the following words terms and phrases shall have the following meanings except where the context clearly indicates otherwise a appointed officer shall mean the city administrator the city attorney or the municipal judge without regard to whether such officer is or is not considered for federal income tax purposes to be an independent contractor b board and commission member shall mean any person duly appointed by the mayor or city council to any board or commission of the city as authorized in the city charter or this municipal city official shall mean a member of city council an appointed officer an employee a designated independent contractor or a board and commission member d designated independent contractor means and shall include any person who 1 provides services on behalf of the city as an official who has discretionary authority with respect to the interpretation andor enforcement of any code regulation or published standard applicable in the city  2 is compensated pursuant to contract by the city for performing such services  and 3 is considered for federal income tax purposes to be an independent contractor e employee shall mean each compensated person in the service of the city who is designated as an employee in accordance with the citys personnel rules and regulations f gift shall mean the transfer of a thing of value by one person to another person without the person transferring the thing of value receiving in return lawful compensation or consideration of equal or greater value from the person receiving the thing of value however a gift shall not mean any thing of value given to a person by the federal government or by a state or local government as authorized by law g official act or official action means any vote decision recommendation approval disapproval or other action including inaction which involves the use of discretionary authority h person shall mean any individual corporation business trust estate trust limited liability company partnership labor organization association political party committee or other legal entity person shall not include the federal government a state or local government or the colorado municipal league i thing of value shall mean any tangible or intangible thing having a market value including without limitation money real property personal property services loans of money or property favors gratuities rewards awards grants scholarships stipends discounts promises of future employment honoraria event tickets travel lodging meals and the forbearance and forgiveness of debt   prohibited gifts a a city official shall not solicit or accept any gift or thing of value from any person either directly or indirectly city officials spouse or dependent child which the city official knows or which a reasonable person in the city officials position should know under the circumstances is either 1 a gift or thing of value that would tend to improperly influence that city official to depart from the faithful and impartial discharge of his or her public duties  or 2 is a gift or thing of value being solicited or given for the primary purpose of rewarding the city official for an official action he or she has taken b a city official shall not solicit or accept any gift or other thing of value from a professional lobbyist as that term is defined in 5 of of the colorado constitution this provision is not intended and shall not be construed to prohibit city officials from attending andor participating in seminars workshops conferences business meetings and similar sessions and events hosted sponsored or arranged by the colorado municipal league or to partake of food beverages andor entertainment offered or provided at such functions   permitted gifts a the prohibitions of not apply if the gift or thing of value is 1 a campaign contribution as defined by law  2 a nonmonetary award publicly presented in recognition of public service  3 an educational scholarship stipend grant or other form of student financial aid that is offered and available to members of the general public similarly situated and is given based upon i merit  ii demonstrated financial need  iii athletic ability  or iv any other factor unrelated to the anticipated or past performance of an official act by a city official  4 a donation loan grant or service provided for medical respite or hospice care or other social welfare needs  provided that such donation loan grant or service is available to members of the general public similarly situated and is unrelated to the anticipated or past performance of an official act by a city official  5 a donation loan grant service or item of tangible personal property offered or given to assist a person or family impacted by a natural disaster or as the victim of a crime  provided that such donation loan grant service or item of tangible personal property is available to similarly situated members of the general public and is unrelated to the anticipated or past performance of an official act by a city official  6 an occasional unsolicited gift having a fair market value of less than fifty dollars $5000  7 unsolicited informational material publications or subscriptions related to the city officials performance of his or her official duties  8 an unsolicited token or award of appreciation in the form of a plaque trophy desk item wall memento or similar item  9 payment of or reimbursement for actual and necessary expenditures for registration travel lodging and meals for attendance at a convention training seminar or other meeting at which the city official is scheduled to participate as a representative of the city or to attend as part of his or her official duties  10 an occasional unsolicited opportunity to participate in a business meeting or social function where a meal is served andor entertainment is provided if the city officials attendance would not be considered extraordinary when viewed in light of the position held by the city official  11 a payment received by a city official for a speech appearance or publication required to be reported by the city official pursuant to crs   12 compensation received by a city official from the city as authorized in the citys charter ordinances policies andor personnel rules and regulations  13 an unsolicited gift given by a relative or a personal friend to a city official on a special occasion that is unrelated to his or her performance of duties for or on behalf of the city and is not intended to influence the city official in the performance of official acts or to reward such city official for official action previously taken  and 14 a gift solicited or received by the spouse or by a dependent child of a city official that is unrelated to the city officials performance of his or her official duties for the city and which is not intended to influence the city officials performance of official acts or to reward the city official for official action previously taken   violations a it shall be unlawful for any city official to violate proof of a violation shall be established by the evidence admitted at trial before the caon city municipal court the standard of proof in any such trial shall be proof by a preponderance of the evidence b the caon city municipal court is hereby authorized to conduct trials with respect to alleged violations of city officials and to impose the civil penalties provided for in of this section c any city official determined by the municipal court to have violated be deemed to have committed a civil infraction the penalty for a city official who is found to have violated said be a civil judgment in an amount equal to twice the fair market value of the prohibited gift solicited or received by the city official as determined by the evidence admitted by the municipal court if the city official fails to pay such judgment within thirty 30 days following the entry of the final judgment or such longer period as may be authorized by order of the municipal court the city may pursue any legal means available to it for the collection of the judgment d nothing in this chapter is intended to preclude the bringing and prosecution of criminal proceedings in a state court of competent jurisdiction against a city official who is accused of committing any crime described in of of title 18 colorado revised statutes a civil judgment entered by the municipal court in a proceeding brought pursuant to this chapter shall be in addition to and not in lieu of any criminal penalty that might be imposed upon conviction in any such criminal proceeding   municipal ethics commission a there is hereby created a municipal ethics commission to be composed of three 3 members the purposes of the municipal ethics commission shall be to receive appropriate cases  and to recommend the instigation of municipal court proceedings in appropriate circumstances the municipal ethics commission also may issue advisory opinions on ethics issues and questions arising under this chapter and may establish a local repository for disclosure statements voluntarily filed by city officials respecting permitted gifts received by them their spouses andor their dependent children b the municipal ethics commission shall have authority to adopt reasonable rules that are not inconsistent with the provisions of this section which may be necessary for purposes of administering and enforcing the provisions of this section c city council shall do those things necessary to provide staff assistance and the funding necessary to allow the municipal ethics commission to carry out its duties pursuant to this section members of the commission shall receive no compensation for their services on the commission but may have their reasonable expenses paid or reimbursed by the city d membership on the municipal ethics commission shall be established as follows 1 the city council shall appoint two 2 members of the commission at a regular or special meeting of city council  2 each of the two 2 appointed members shall be a resident of the city and neither shall be a city official  3 public notice of the availability of positions on the municipal commission that are required or permitted in this subsection shall require a majority vote of the commission j settlement offers 1 the commission may propose settlements with respect to alleged violations of the city official named in a complaint such proposals shall be made in writing and shall designate the amount of a proposed resolution penalty settlement proposals shall be accepted or rejected in writing by the city official within twenty 20 days following the date of the offer a failure to respond shall be deemed a rejection 2 the proposed resolution penalty shall represent the amount that the commission believes based upon its investigation is equal to twice the value of a gift or thing of value improperly solicited or accepted by the city official or when applicable the city officials spouse or dependent child 3 if a resolution penalty is proposed accepted and paid the name of the city official the essential details of the alleged violation and the amount of the resolution penalty paid by the city official shall be included in a summary report prepared by the commission and filed with the city clerk such summary report shall be a public record 4 if a proposed settlement is not accepted or if an agreedupon resolution penalty is not paid with thirty 30 days following the acceptance of a settlement offer the matter will be referred to the citys municipal court prosecutor who shall make the ultimate decision regarding whether municipal court proceedings will be instigated 5 the municipal prosecutor shall do what is necessary to instigate and prosecute such proceedings unless he or she believes in good faith that sufficient evidence to support a civil judgment authorized in c could not be presented in a municipal court proceeding if the matter is referred the fact that a settlement proposal was made shall be kept confidential and shall not be offered or admitted as evidence at trial 6 resolution penalties paid by city officials shall be    definitions the definitions of the words contained in this chapter shall be as defined in title 39 crs as may be amended which definitions are incorporated herein by this reference the city further adopts all rules and regulations adopted by the colorado department of revenue and such rules and regulations are incorporated herein by this reference   transactions subject to sales tax and exemptions a the transaction subject to the sales tax shall be as set forth below and as required by colorado state law 1 the tangible personal property and services taxable hereunder shall be the same as the tangible personal property and services taxable pursuant to crs except as provided herein and shall be subject to the same exemptions as those specified in of of title 39 crs expressly including the following exemptions a for vending machine sales of food specified in crs 2 b for sales by a charitable organization specified in crs 1b c for sales of items of personal property machines in the amount of fifteen cents or less as specified in crs d for sales of farm equipment and farm equipment under lease or contract as specified in crs 2b and 2c e for sales that benefit a colorado school specified in crs f for sales by an association or organization of parents and teachers of public school students that is a charitable organization as specified in crs 1c g for manufactured homes as specified in crs 3 2 the sales tax shall not be imposed on the sale of construction and building materials as the term is used in crs if such materials are picked up by the purchaser and if the purchaser of such materials presents to the retailer a building permit or other acceptable documentation that a local use tax has been paid or is required to be paid on the value thereof 3 the sales tax shall not be imposed on the sale of personal property on which a specific ownership tax has been paid or is payable if a the purchaser is a nonresident of or has its principal place of business outside the city and b such personal property is registered or required to be registered outside the limits of the city under the laws of the state of colorado 4 the sales tax shall not be imposed on the sale of tangible personal property at retail or the furnishing of services if the transaction has been previously subjected to a sales or use tax lawfully imposed on the purchaser or user by another statutory or home rule county equal to or in excess of the amount imposed by this chapter a credit shall be granted against the sales tax payable with respect to such transaction equal in amount to the lawfully imposed sales or use tax previously paid by the purchaser or user to such other statutory or home rule county provided that such credit shall not exceed the amount imposed by this chapter   determination of place at which sales are consummated all retail sales shall be considered consummated at the place of business of the retailer unless the tangible personal property sold is delivered by the retailer or its agent to a destination outside the city or to a common carrier for delivery to a destination outside the limits of the city the gross taxable sales shall include delivery charges when such charges are subject to the state sales and use tax imposed by of title 39 crs regardless of the place to which delivery is made if a retailer has no permanent place of business in the city or has more than one place of business the place or places at which the retail sales are consummated for the purpose of this sales tax shall be determined by the provisions of of title 39 crs and by the rules and regulations promulgated by the colorado department of revenue the amount subject to the sales tax shall not include the amount of any state sales and use tax imposed by of title 39 crs   credit for sales taxes previously paid the citys sales tax shall not apply to the sale of tangible personal property at retail or the furnishing of services if the transaction was previously subjected to a sales or use tax lawfully imposed on the purchaser or user by another statutory or home rule municipality equal to or in excess of the sales tax imposed by the city a credit shall be granted against the citys sales tax with respect to such transaction equal in an amount to the lawfully imposed local sales or use tax previously paid by the purchaser or user to the previous statutory or home rule municipality the amount of the credit shall however not exceed the sales tax imposed by the city upon the sale   collection administration and enforcement the collection administration and enforcement of the sales tax shall be performed by the executive director of the colorado department of revenue the executive director in the same manner as the collection administration and enforcement of the colorado state sales tax the provisions of of title 39 crs and all rules and regulations promulgated thereunder by the executive director shall govern the collection administration and enforcement of the sales tax   vendor fee a a retailers collection and remittance expense vendors fee equal to 333 percent of the amount of sales taxes collected and reported may be claimed on each sales tax return timely filed in accordance with the requirements of this retained by such retailer as a credit against sales taxes paid on or before the date upon which such taxes were due except that the amount of such credit shall not exceed two hundred dollars $20000 per month b any vendors fee that otherwise would be available as a credit to any retailer shall be forfeited if the sales tax return upon which such vendors fee may be claimed is not filed on or before its due date or if the sales taxes payable to the city with respect to such sales tax return are not paid when due  use tax  use tax imposed a there is levied a tax upon the privilege of using storing distributing or consuming in the city any article of tangible personal property or taxable services specified in the rate levied shall be two percent 2% b in addition to the use tax levied in subsection a above there is an additional use tax of a rate of one percent levied upon the privilege of using storing distributing or consuming in the city any article of tangible personal property or taxable services specified in which shall be used exclusively for streetrelated infrastructure improvements and repairs this additional use tax shall terminate on  c imposition and collection the taxes specified in this section are imposed upon and payable by the taxpayer the taxes shall be computed in accordance with schedules or systems approved and specified by the finance director d continuation the taxes imposed in this section shall continue to be levied and collected until amended or repealed by ordinance e tax cumulative the taxes imposed in this section shall be in addition to all other taxes imposed by law   definitions the definitions of the words contained in this chapter shall be as defined in title 39 crs as may be amended which definitions are incorporated herein by this reference except as provided in this section a automotive vehicle means any vehicle or device in upon or by which any person or property is or may be transported or drawn upon a public highway or any device used or designed for aviation or flight in the air automotive vehicle includes but is not limited to motor vehicles trailers semitrailers or mobile homes automotive vehicle shall not include devices moved by human power or used exclusively upon stationary rails or tracks b construction materials means tangible personal property which when combined with other tangible personal property loses its identity to become an integral and inseparable part of a completed structure or project including public and private improvements construction materials include but are not limited to such things as asphalt bricks builders hardware caulking material cement concrete conduit electric wiring and connections fireplace inserts electrical heating and cooling equipment flooring glass gravel insulation lath lead lime lumber macadam millwork mortar oil paint piping pipe valves and pipe fittings plaster plumbing fixtures putty reinforcing mesh road base roofing sand sanitary sewer pipe sheet metal site lighting steel stone stucco tile trees shrubs and other landscaping materials wall board wall coping wall paper weather stripping wire netting and screen water mains and meters and wood preserver the above materials when used for forms or other items which do not remain as an integral or inseparable part of a completed structure or project are not construction materials c consumer means any person in the city who purchases uses stores distributes or otherwise consumes tangible personal property or taxable services purchased from sources inside or outside the city d storage means any keeping or retention of or exercise dominion or control over or possession of for any length of time tangible personal property not while in transit but on a stand still basis for future use when leased rented or purchased at retail from sources either within or without the city from any person or vendor e taxpayer means any person obligated to pay tax under the terms of this chapter f use means the exercise for any length of time by any person within the city of any right power or dominion over tangible personal property or services when rented leased or purchased at retail from sources either within or without the city from any person or vendor or used in the performance of a contract in the city whether such tangible personal property is owned or not owned by the taxpayer use also includes the withdrawal of items from inventory for consumption   transactions subject to use tax and exemptions a the use tax levied by apply only to the price of the following 1 construction or building materials which are used or consumed in the city and upon which a sales or use tax has not been paid 2 all items of stock or inventory originally purchased at wholesale by a person engaged in business in the city but only to the extent that such item is removed from stock or inventory and consumed by such person or distributed to any other person for use or consumption by any means or transaction other than a retail sale items with respect to which the use tax will apply shall include but not be limited to goods given as samples or prizes for purposes of promoting business sales or goodwill by persons engaged in business in the city 3 all items of tangible personal property originally purchased at wholesale and stored by any person engaged in manufacturing in the city but only to the extent that such item is removed from stock and consumed by such person or distributed to any other person for use or consumption by any means or transaction other than a retail sale 4 all items of tangible personal property leased or rented from persons outside the city by persons residing in the city or persons engaged in business in the city if such item of tangible personal property is used in the business but only to the extent that a sales tax on the price of such item has not been paid to the city 5 automotive vehicles required by the statutes of colorado to be registered at an address inside the city on which a municipal sales tax has not been paid the county clerk of the county in which the registration occurs is authorized to collect such tax for the city prior to or at the time of registration a the determination of vehicle registration requirements for individuals shall be the same as for the determination of residency for voter registration purposes b the determination of vehicle registration requirements for automotive vehicles which are owned by a business and operated primarily for business purposes shall be based on the address from which such automotive vehicles are principally operated and maintained b the use tax levied by not extend or apply to the following 1 the storage use or consumption of any tangible personal property the sale of which is subject to a retail sales tax imposed by the city  2 automotive vehicles if the owner is or was at the time of purchase a nonresident of the city who purchased the vehicle for use outside the city and if the vehicle was previously registered titled and licensed outside the city c the list of exemptions shall not be increased by implication or similarity d the burden of proving that any consumer is exempt from paying the use tax shall be on such consumer under such reasonable requirements of proof as the finance director may prescribe   provisions relative to building permits a except as otherwise provided by subsection c of this section every person who shall build construct reconstruct alter expand modify or improve any building dwelling unit or other structure or improvement to real property and who shall purchase construction materials as defined in this chapter supplies and other tangible personal property used consumed or stored on real property improvements andor attached or affixed structures located within the city shall pay the city the use tax provided for in this chapter on construction materials whether purchased from sources inside or outside the city in either of the following two 2 ways at the option of the finance director 1 estimated prepayment the estimated cost of such construction materials shall be calculated by multiplying the estimated value of this construction project entered on the building permit by the city by a percentage established by the finance director use tax on such estimated cost of construction materials shall be paid at the time the building permit is issued if use tax is prepaid interest on any tax deficiency related to construction materials shall be computed from the date of issuance of the certificate of occupancy or temporary certificate of occupancy whichever is earlier 2 actual cost the actual cost of such construction materials shall be reported and tax paid on monthly returns if the permit issued is in the amount of fifty thousand dollars $5000000 or more and on quarterly returns if the permit issued is for less than fifty thousand dollars $5000000 if use tax is paid on actual cost basis interest on any tax deficiency shall be computed from the date on which tax is due b no final certificate of occupancy or final inspection in lieu of permanent certificate of occupancy shall be issued unless all tax due on construction materials for the project for which the building permit was issued has been paid or arrangement therefor has been made with the finance director any temporary certificate of occupancy shall be revoked if the use tax payable pursuant to this chapter has not been paid within ninety 90 days of issuance c no use tax shall be due on construction materials used in construction projects undertaken and managed directly by the city d no person shall make any false statement in connection with this section   duty to keep books and recordsaudit a it shall be the duty of every person firm or corporation liable to the city for any use tax under this section to keep and preserve records for a period of at least three 3 years after completion of construction activities subject to a use tax such records shall include all books accounts and records together with all bills receipts invoices cash register tapes or other documents of original entry supporting the entries in the books including subcontractors detailed invoices for goods and services b every person shall provide all such records for audit by the finance director during normal business hours c the city may conduct an audit to recompute the use tax by reviewing and evaluating the actual cost of construction materials if any recomputed use tax is less than that shown and paid by the taxpayer the difference shall be refunded to the taxpayer if the recomputed use tax is more than that shown and paid by the taxpayer the taxpayer shall be notified of the deficiency and shall be required to pay the same   refunds a within sixty 60 days of the date of final inspection by the building official if no certificate of occupancy will be issued or on the date of issuance of a certificate of be allowed one thirty 30 day extension of time if the taxpayer requests the extension prior to the expiration of the sixty 60 day period of time described herein failure to so notify the finance director and provide the required records shall be grounds for denying a refund request upon receipt of the timely request for a refund complete with required records the finance director shall determine whether in his or her reasonable opinion receipts for all of the material used have been provided and shall make a determination of whether a refund of any excess use taxes paid may be given b whenever the finance director discovers from the examination of a return or pursuant to an audit of a taxpayers records that the taxpayer has overpaid use taxes due the city the finance director shall issue a refund for payment of the excess taxes to the taxpayer plus interest at the rate established by this chapter unless the overpayment and interest are applied to offset other tax due the director shall keep a duplicate of said refund and also a statement that sets forth the reason why such refund was ordered   interest any use tax due and unpaid shall be a debt to the city and shall from state of colorado sources identified at parts 3 and 5 of title 16 crs or from federal sources pursuant to federal laws rules and regulations the receipt use and disposition of which are authorized by crs   special provisions a the seizureforfeiture fund is designated as the lawfully created fund to receive proceeds from property forfeited to the federal government and allocated to the caon city police department pursuant to federal law and regulation b for accounting purposes the seizureforfeiture fund shall be treated as a special reserve account which will have two divisions one such division shall receive proceeds from federally forfeited property allocated by an agency or officer of the united states government and the other division shall receive proceeds from property forfeited pursuant to state law the assets of each division shall not be commingled c all forfeited property and all proceeds from forfeited property received by or on behalf of the caon city police department shall be subject to the reporting and audit requirements set forth at crs d all such forfeited property and all proceeds from forfeited property received by or on behalf of the caon city police department shall be used and expended only as approved and authorized by the committee on disposition required under crs no expenditure shall be authorized except by a majority vote of all committee members a memorandum regarding each expenditure authorized by the committee shall be made and shall reflect the vote of each committee member e the composition of the committee shall be as provided in 3 crs the initial representative of the council of caon city shall be the city administrator the council reserves the right to designate a replacement representative at any time and from time to time by resolution the committee is specifically authorized to establish and maintain one or more bank accounts to be used for law enforcement purposes designated by the committee and to deposit into such account or accounts assets of the seizureforfeiture fund f in accordance with applicable federal and state law moneys in the seizureforfeiture fund shall not be subject to appropriation by the council of caon city nor shall such moneys be used or expended for any purpose that is prohibited by applicable federal or state law or for any permitted purpose that is not specifically authorized by the committee g any interest or other revenue generated on account of the investment of moneys in the seizureforfeiture fund shall remain in the fund  recovery of fees and licensee the license shall be deemed suspended until another licensed natural person is registered with the building official such person shall provide personal supervision at the work job or project site adhering to reasonable attention to the job site to insure proper construction as determined by the city c the following persons are exempt from the licensing requirements of this chapter 1 a general contractor class a this license entitles the licensee to construct remodel or repair any commercial or residential structure or addition thereto including tenant finish for which a building permit is required this license does not allow work that includes electrical plumbing mechanical signs fire and burglar alarms fire protection and trades outside the license holders area of expertise b general contractor class b this license entitles the licensee to construct remodel or repair commercial or residential buildings not exceeding three stories in height for which a building permit is required this license does not allow work that includes electrical plumbing mechanical signs fire and burglar alarms fire protection and other trades outside the license holders area of expertise c general contractor class c this license entitles the licensee to construct remodel or repair any residential building this license does not allow work that includes electrical plumbing mechanical signs fire and burglar alarms fire protection and other trades outside the license holders area of expertise d mechanical class m a mechanical license entitles the holder to install maintain alter or repair mechanical systems that are permanently installed and utilized to provide control of environmental conditions and related process within buildings this shall include evaporative refrigeration systems and related appurtenances e trade class d a trade license may be issued to a contractor who specializes in a specific trade listed in this an applicant may obtain a trade license for up to four 4 trades   licensedenial or revocation conditions any license issued pursuant to this chapter may be revoked suspended or refused to any person firm or corporation that intentionally violates the shall be given a copy of the complaint and at least twenty 20 days written notice of the time and place of the hearing the notice shall be served personally or shall be mailed by first class mail to the licensees last known mailing address at the hearing the licensee shall have the right to present his or her case by oral or documentary evidence to submit rebuttal evidence and to conduct such crossexamination as may be required for a full and true disclosure of the facts the licensee shall be entitled at said hearing to have the benefit of legal counsel of his or her own choosing and own expense b the city administrator after review of the evidence presented shall have the power to suspend or revoke the license or take other disciplinary action on the license including the issuance of a formal letter of reprimand  or order the licensee to pay unpaid permit fees and inspection or investigative costs incurred by the city  or impose a probationary period during which time any further violations would result in automatic suspension or revocation of the license the city administrator may take any of the foregoing actions if the city administrator finds that the licensee committed other authorized representative of the city  3 use of the license or registration to obtain permits required under the building codes for any other person  4 misrepresentation of a material fact when applying for a license or fraud in obtaining a license  5 gross negligence in the work done by the licensee  6 failure to obtain a permit required under this   7 failure to give written notice to the building official of any matter for which notice is required by this chapter  or 8 conviction of an offense involving misapplication of funds or property received from another c emergency suspension trash garbage refuse and rubbish collection  definitions as used in this chapter compensation means any money property service or thing of value charged or received or to be charged or received whether directly or indirectly motor vehicle means any automobile truck tractor bus or other selfpropelled vehicle or any trailer drawn thereby excluding vehicles operated upon fixed rails person means any individual partnership limited liability company corporation association or other legal entity but does not include the city of caon city or any of its departments or employees trash haulage license means a license issued to a trash hauler pursuant to the requirements and other provisions of this chapter trash haulage purpose means any activity of a trash hauler involving the use of streets alleys and other public thoroughfares in the city for the collection hauling or transportation for compensation of any trash garbage refuse rubbish or other waste material of any kind trash hauler means any person who uses the streets alleys and other public thoroughfares in the city for the collection hauling or transportation for compensation of any trash garbage refuse rubbish or other waste material of any kind   licenserequired a beginning  no person shall use any street alley or other public thoroughfare in the city for the collection hauling or transporting for compensation of any trash garbage refuse rubbish or other waste materials of any kind unless such person holds a valid trash haulage license issued pursuant to this chapter or is exempt under of this section b the following persons are not required to obtain a trash haulage license 1 a civic community benevolent or charitable nonprofit organization that collects transports and markets materials for resource recovery solely for the purpose of raising funds for a charitable civic or benevolent activity  2 a person who transports trash or recyclable materials produced by such person  3 a property owner or agent thereof who transports trash or recyclable materials left by a tenant upon such owners property so long as such property owner does not provide trash collection service for compensation for tenants on a regular or continuing basis  4 a demolition or construction contractor or landscaper who produces and transports trash other than garbage in the course of such occupation where the trash produced is merely incidental to the particular demolition or construction work being performed by such person  5 a tree trimming service lawn care service or garden care service contractor who in the normal course of his or her occupation produces yard rubbish including tree branches twigs grass shrub clippings weeds leaves and other general yard garden and organic waste material and transports such materials from places where such contractor works as an incidental portion of the work being performed by such contractor 6 a person hauling trash as the citys agent pursuant to a nuisance abatement action     trash haulage licenseapplication and fee a applications for trash haulage licenses shall be made to the city clerk on forms provided for that purpose b no of the colorado department of revenue and is qualified to conduct an alcohol beverage tasting  c the dates and times in which the licensee intends to conduct tastings events  d a permit fee of one hundred twenty dollars $12000 5 advance notification no alcohol can be provided as samples during a tasting until the licensee has provided written notice to the city clerks office at least five 5 business days prior to conducting said tasting such notice shall contain the specific days and hours on which the tasting will occur 6 renewal of tasting permits shall be concurrent with the renewal of licenses for retail liquor stores and liquorlicensed drugstores a licensees initial tasting permit shall expire on the same date as the date of the licensees underlying liquor license the initial tastings permit application fee shall be prorated if the permit expires in less than one year renewal permits shall be issued for a period of time concurrent with the underlying license 7 tasting permits shall be conspicuously and prominently posted by the licensee on the licensed premises at all times during business hours 8 a tasting permit shall only be valid when issued to a retail liquor store or a liquorlicensed drugstore licensee whose license is valid and is in full force and effect b limitations on tastings tastings within the city of caon city shall be subject to the following limitations 1 tastings shall be conducted only by a person who has completed a server training program that meets the standards established by the liquor enforcement division of the colorado department of revenue and who is either a retail liquor store licensee or a liquorlicensed drugstore licensee or an employee of such licensee and only on a licensees licensed premises  2 the alcohol beverages used in tastings shall be purchased licensed wholesaler licensed brew pub or winery licensed pursuant to crs at a cost that is not less than the laidin cost for such alcohol  3 the size of an individual sample shall not exceed one ounce for malt or vinous liquor or onehalf ounce for spirituous liquors  4 the licensee shall not serve nor allow to be consumed by any one patron more than four 4 individual samples to a patron during a tasting  5 tastings shall not exceed a total of five 5 hours in duration per day which need not be consecutive  6 tastings shall be conducted only during the operating hours during which the licensee on whose premises the tastings occur is permitted to sell alcohol beverages and in no case earlier than eleven am or later than nine pm  7 the licensee shall prohibit patrons from leaving the licensed premises with an unconsumed sample  8 the licensee shall promptly remove all open and unconsumed beverage samples from the licensed premises or shall destroy the samples immediately following the completion of the tasting  9 the licensee shall not serve a person who is under twentyone 21 years of age or who is visibly intoxicated  10 the samples used in the tastings shall be served in open containers and shall be provided to a patron free of charge  11 tastings may occur on no more than one hundred fiftysix 156 days per year  12 no manufacturer of spirituous or vinous liquors shall induce a licensee goods or financial or inkind assistance to favor the manufacturers products being sampled at a tasting the licensee shall bear the financial and all other responsibility for a tasting c violations 1 a violation of this section whether by the licensees employees agents or otherwise shall be the responsibility of the licensee who is conducting the alcohol tasting 2 licensees conducting a tasting shall be subject to the same revocation suspension and enforcement provisions as otherwise apply to those licensees    6    distance restrictions not applicable to restaurant and hotel licenses the five hundred 500 foot distance restriction set forth in crs  4433131di shall be eliminated within the corporate boundaries of the city of caon city for hotel and restaurant licenses only any applicant who otherwise qualifies under the terms and provisions of the colorado liquor receive a hotel and restaurant license shall not be denied such license for reasons having to do with the proximity of the building in which liquor is to be sold under such hotel and restaurant license to any land used for school purposes     administrative applications a city clerk administrative applications may be decided by the city clerk upon receipt of a completed application and such fees as are required by this chapter and the state liquor laws b administrative application shall mean the application on forms approved by the city or the state for special event permits and renewals c referrals the city clerk shall refer to the local licensing authority for decision all administrative applications when the city clerk has reason to believe that violations of this chapter or the state liquor laws not previously reviewed by the authority may have occurred on the licensed premises during the previous license period in addition the city clerk may refer to the local licensing authority for decision any administrative application when as determined by the city clerk the public interest would be best served by the determination of the matter by the authority d appeals administrative applications that are denied by the city clerk may be appealed to the local licensing authority appeals must be submitted in writing to the city clerk within ten 10 days of the denial and may include a request for hearing appeals to the authority will be decided de novo  merchant patrol and security guard services and security guards  definitions as used in this chapter the following words shall have the meanings as provided herein a merchant patrol or security guard service means any person partnership or corporation which conducts or is engaged in the business of guarding or keeping a surveillance upon business industrial or similar premises or providing protection to persons and property by maintaining or providing on or near any premises one or more security guards b security guard means any natural person employed by a licensed merchant patrol or security guard service for the purpose of watching guarding or otherwise protecting the persons or property on any premises not his or her own the term shall include but is not limited to uniformed guards and bouncers performing services as an employee of a licensed merchant patrol or security guard service in premises licensed under articles 3 and 4 of title 44 crs 201 but shall not include individuals employed by any common carrier engaged in interstate commerce industrial or commercial guards employed directly by the owner of an industrial or commercial premises or peace officers acting within the scope of their employment a security guard may be licensed as either an armed security guard or an unarmed security guard c license officer means the city clerk d approved security guard program means an accredited training program including curriculum for security guards approved by the chief of police e approved firearms course means a firearms training program including curriculum approved by the chief of police     unlawful acts it is unlawful a for any person partnership or corporation to engage in the merchant patrol or security guard service business without first being licensed under this chapter b for a merchant patrol or security guard service to employ as a security guard any person who is not licensed as a security guard under this chapter c for any person who is not licensed as a security guard under this chapter to perform services as a security guard d for any person to perform services as a security guard for a merchant patrol or security guard service which is not licensed under this chapter   application for license application for either a merchant patrol or security guard service license or security guard license shall be submitted on forms provided by the city and shall contain at least the following information a for a merchant patrol or security guard service license 1 the full name age residence present occupation and occupations for the preceding five 5 years of each individual applicant of each partner if a partnership and of the managing officer and each stockholder of ten percent 10% or more stock if a corporation such application shall show available facts relating to the character competency and integrity of the applicant partner or managing officer and shall list any felony misdemeanor or ordinance violations for which the applicant partner or managing officer was convicted within the ten 10 year period preceding the filing of the application other than minor traffic violations the nature of the offense the penalty imposed and the date and place where such offense occurred 2 other documents as deemed necessary by the city clerk or the chief of police b for an armed security guard license 1 the full name date of birth residence present occupation and past occupations and all addresses for the preceding five 5 years of the applicant and the name and address of the merchant patrol or security guard service by whom he or she is to be employed 2 a list of all felony misdemeanor or ordinance violation convictions other than minor traffic violations of the applicant during the ten 10 years immediately preceding the filing of the application as to each such conviction such list shall indicate a the date of the offense  b the place where the offense occurred  c the date of conviction  d the identity of the court entering the judgment of conviction  e the penalty imposed  f the date upon which the applicant satisfied the requirements of the penalty ie paid the fine completed serving a jail or prison sentence completed probation etc 3 a list indicating as to the ten 10 year period immediately preceding the filing of the application a whether the applicant had received mental health counseling and if so indicating when where and why such counseling was received and giving the name and address of the mental health practitioner or facility involved  b whether the applicant had been voluntarily or involuntarily committed for psychiatric or mental health treatment and if so indicating when where and why such commitment occurred and giving the name and address of the practitioner or facility providing the psychiatric or mental health treatment  c whether the applicant has had any chemical use or abuse problems or whether the applicant has voluntarily or involuntarily participated in or was ordered by a court or otherwise committed to a treatment program for substance abuse or addiction if so the applicant shall furnish details as to the matter sufficient to advise as to when where and why the problems occurred and describe the treatment program participated in by the applicant 4 a full set of fingerprints to be provided at the applicants expense 5 documentation that the applicant has successfully completed an approved security guard program and an approved firearms course 6 a statement that the applicant is not currently employed as a peace officer or that the applicant if currently employed as a peace officer will not serve as a security guard while being so employed no security guard license shall be issued to a currently employed peace officer 7 in the case of an alien proper work documents indicating that the applicant is lawfully in the united states and entitled to employment in this country 8 other documents as deemed necessary by the city clerk or the chief of police c for an unarmed security guard license all of the information required for an armed security guard license except that documentation that the applicant has completed an approved firearms course will not be required     issuance or denial of licenses a upon submission of a completed application to the license officer and payment of the fee provided for at the license officer shall cause the application to be transmitted to the chief of police or designee for investigation of the accuracy of the application and the character integrity and competency of the applicant thereafter the chief of police shall report his or her findings and recommendations in a timely manner to the license officer who shall either grant or deny the application b the license officer shall deny an application for any of the following reasons 1 the applicant is under the age of twentyone 21 years or if an alien has failed to produce proper work documents 2 the character and reputation and past conduct of the applicant is unsatisfactory 3 the applicant has been convicted of a felony or a misdemeanor or ordinance violation involving moral turpitude or any crime of violence within ten 10 years immediately preceding the date of application or if the applicant had been imprisoned with respect to any such conviction at any time within the five 5 years immediately preceding the filing of the application 4 the applicant has had a civil judgment entered against him or her for fraud theft deceit or misrepresentation within the ten 10 years immediately preceding the date of application which has not been paid or otherwise satisfied 5 the applicant is addicted to drugs or is habitually intoxicated or has a history of emotional or psychiatric instability 6 an applicant for a security guard license has not satisfactorily indicated he or she will be employed by a licensed merchant patrol or security guard service 7 an applicant for a security guard license has failed to provide acceptable documentation that the applicant has successfully completed an approved security guard program and if required an approved firearms course this requirement will apply to all applicants including former law enforcement officers c upon approval of an application payment of license fees and posting of a sufficient and proper bond and where required proof of adequate insurance all as provided in this chapter the license officer shall issue the license   schedule of fees a license fees payable to the city of caon city shall further conditioned on the faithful performance and honest conduct of all security guards employed by the licensee and will pay all judgments rendered against such applicant for any violation of such ordinances or conditions and hold the city harmless on account of the issuance of such license such bond shall remain in force and be binding for the period of the license and may be continued from decrease in coverage or cancellation of the policy all such insurance must be maintained and remain in full force and effect during the period for which the license will be issued     prohibited practices a security guards shall not carry firearms while in the course of their employment for any merchant patrol or security guard service unless the merchant patrol or security guard service certifies in writing to the chief of police that such security guard has successfully completed an approved firearms course nothing herein shall be construed to permit a security guard to carry an illegal weapon or to carry any concealed weapon b security guards shall not arrest any person except as permitted by law for any citizen c security guards shall not represent themselves in any manner to be a peace officer or as having any police authority d security guards shall not wear any uniforms unless same are first approved by the chief of police no uniform shall be deceptively similar to any uniform worn by any law enforcement agency in the county of fremont nor shall any uniform bear the words police or officer anywhere thereon   renewal of license renewals for licenses issued
