safe or free passage of a pedestrian or vehicle by any means where pedestrians and traffic are present including unreasonably causing a pedestrian or vehicle operator to take evasive action to avoid contact is a public safety concern without regard to the speech of the individual who is intentionally blocking obstructing or interfering with the safe or free passage of a pedestrian or vehicle and that such conduct should be regulated to address the public safety concerns caused by individuals taking evasive action to avoid such contact b definitions obstruct shall mean to walk stand sit lie or place an object in such a manner as to hinder or slow progress to retard progress to make accomplishment of obtaining a goal slower or more difficult or to impede another person or vehicle or to require another person or a driver of a vehicle to take evasive action to avoid physical contact acts authorized as an exercise of ones constitutional right to picket or legally protest or acts authorized by permit issued by the city shall not constitute obstruction c prohibited acts 1 it is unlawful for any person to obstruct either alone or in consort with others a any portion of any street or highway located between the sidewalks or between the curbs or on any portion of the vehiculartraveled portion of any street highway or alley which does not have abutting sidewalks or curbs in such a manner that hinders or impedes the free and uninterrupted passage of vehicles  b any sidewalk in such a manner that hinders or impedes the free and uninterrupted passage of pedestrians  c any portion of any city trail in a manner which hinders or impedes the free and uninterrupted passage of pedestrians or city staff performing trail maintenance  or d any portion of a city park or other city property in manner which hinders or impedes the ability of city staff to perform maintenance of or similar actions in such areas and after city staff has made a request that the individual relocate while staff conducts maintenance or actions referred to herein d affirmative defense 1 it is an affirmative defense to a violation of this section that a person a stands sits kneels reclines or lies down due to a medical emergency b as a result of a medically confirmable disability utilizes a wheelchair walker or other similar mobility supporting device to move c operating or patronizing a commercial establishment or vending cart or carrying out other activities pursuant to a license permit or other authorization d stands sits or kneels when attending a parade festival performance rally demonstration meeting or similar special event conducted in the public rightofway pursuant to any permit or license issued by the city e sits upon an object intended for sitting furnished by the city or by any other public agency this defense shall not apply to requests made by city staff under subsection c1d of this section f sits upon a public sidewalk at or near a transit stop while waiting for public transportation 2 no law enforcement officer shall issue a citation make an arrest or otherwise enforce this section against any person unless the person engages in conduct prohibited by this section after having first been notified by a law enforcement officer that the conduct violates this section e when law enforcement has frequent and consistent contact with a person violating this section the officer should attempt to ascertain whether the person is in need of medical or human services assistance including but not limited to mental health treatment drug or alcohol rehabilitation or homeless services assistance if the officer determines that the person may be in need of medical or human services assistance the officer should make reasonable efforts to contact and obtain the assistance of a designated human service outreach worker who in turn shall assess the needs of the person and if warranted direct the person to an appropriate provider of medical or human services assistance in lieu of the person being cited or arrested for a violation of this section if the officer is unable to obtain the assistance of a human services outreach worker if the human services outreach worker determines that the person is not in need of medical or human services assistance or if the person refuses to cooperate with the direction of the human services outreach worker the officer may proceed to cite or arrest the person for a violation of this section f penalties any person who violates any provision of this section is guilty of a misdemeanor and upon conviction thereof shall be punished by a fine in an amount that does not exceed the maximum fine provided for in   camping on public property a camping within any parkway recreation area park or other city property is prohibited except as permitted under of the for purposes of this section the following words and phrases shall have the following meanings 1 camping shall mean to reside or dwell temporarily in a place and conduct activities of daily living such as eating or sleeping in such place or establishing or constructing a shelter the term does not include napping during the day or picnicking the phrase during the day means from one hour after sunrise until sunset 2 shelter includes without limitation any tent tarpaulin leanto sleeping bag bedroll blankets or any form of cover or protection from the elements other than clothing 3 reside or dwell includes without limitation conducting such activities as eating sleeping or the storage of personal possessions c no officers of the city of caon city police department shall issue a citation make an arrest or otherwise enforce this section against any person unless the officer orally requests or orders the person to refrain from the alleged violation of this section and if the person fails to comply after receiving the oral request or order the officer tenders a written request or order to the person warning that if the person fails to comply the person may be cited or arrested for a violation of this section d when possible the officer should attempt to ascertain whether the person is in need of medical or human services assistance including but not limited to mental health treatment drug or alcohol rehabilitation or homeless services assistance if the officer determines that the person may be in need of medical or human services assistance the officer should make reasonable efforts to contact and obtain the assistance of a designated human service outreach worker who in turn shall assess the needs of the person and if warranted direct the person to an appropriate provider of medical or human services assistance in lieu of the person being cited or arrested for a violation of this section if the officer is unable to obtain the assistance of a human services outreach worker if the human services outreach worker determines that the person is not in need of medical or human services assistance or if the person refuses to cooperate with the direction of the human services outreach worker the officer may proceed to cite or arrest the person for a violation of this section so long as the warnings required by subsection c of this section have been previously given e cleanup of unauthorized camping sites upon violation of this section officers may remove and store all unclaimed personal property found at an unauthorized camping site illegal items such as illicit drugs and any items that reasonably appear to be evidence of a crime will be turned over to the appropriate law enforcement agency any items otherwise not regarded as having apparent utility or that are in an unsanitary condition will be immediately discarded removal of personal property under this section shall be executed pursuant to the following procedure 1 at least seventytwo 72 hours prior to the proposed cleanup date the city will post a notice stating the date and time of the cleanup the notice will be posted in the general vicinity of the personal property to be removed 2 in the event of the existence of a condition posing an imminent danger of damage or injury to or loss of life limb property or health the city may take immediate action to clean up without notice but under no circumstances may a clean up under this section occur more than twentyfour 24 hours after the discovery of the site by law enforcement 3 personal property removed from illegal camp sites shall be stored in a secure location and shall be held for a period of at least thirty 30 days from the date the cleanup occurred 4 an individual may claim ownership of an item of personal property within thirty 30 days from the last date that the cleanup occurred the city will not return items such as tobacco alcohol or marijuana or products containing tobacco alcohol andor marijuana and will dispose of such products in accordance with its caon city police department policies and procedures for the disposal of illicit substances 5 after the thirty 30 day storage period elapses unclaimed personal property will be disposed of by either discarding recycling or otherwise disposing of such items as determined by who owns manages operates or otherwise controls the use of a premises subject to this chapter to violate any provision of this chapter b it is unlawful for a person to smoke in an area where smoking is prohibited pursuant to this chapter c a person who violates this chapter is guilty of a misdemeanor and upon conviction thereof shall be punished by a fine not to exceed two hundred dollars $200 for a first violation within a calendar year a fine not to exceed three hundred dollars $300 for a second violation within a calendar year and a fine not to exceed five hundred dollars $500 for each additional violation within a calendar year each day of a continuing violation shall be deemed a separate violation  theft  acts constituting theft designated a a person commits theft when he or she knowingly obtains or exercises control over anything of value of another without authorization or by threat or deception and 1 intends to deprive the other person permanently of the use or benefit of the thing of value  or 2 knowingly uses conceals or abandons the thing of value in such a manner as to deprive the other person permanently of its use or benefit  or 3 uses conceals or abandons the thing of value intending that such use concealment or abandonment will deprive the other person permanently of its use and benefit  or 4 demands any consideration to which he or she is not legally entitled as a condition of restoring the thing of value to the other person b the provisions of this section shall be applicable to things having a value of less than three hundred dollars $30000   theft of rental property a a person commits theft of rental property if he or she 1 obtains the temporary use of the personal property of another which is available only for hire by means of threat or deception or knowing that such use is without the consent of the person providing the personal property  or 2 having lawfully obtained possession for temporary use of the personal property of another which is available only for hire knowingly fails to reveal the whereabouts of or fails to return the property to the owner thereof or his or her representative or to the person from whom he or she has received it within seventytwo 72 hours after the time in which he or she agreed to return it b the provisions of this section shall be applicable only to rental property having a value of less than three hundred dollars $30000   concealment of goods a if any person willfully conceals unpurchased goods wares or merchandise owned or held by and offered or displayed by any store or other mercantile establishment whether the concealment is on his or her own person or otherwise and whether on or off the premises of the store or mercantile establishment such concealment constitutes prima facie evidence that the person intended to commit the crime of theft b if any person conceals upon his or her person or otherwise carries away any unpurchased goods wares or merchandise held or owned by any store or mercantile establishment the merchant or any employee thereof or any peace officer acting in good faith and upon probable cause based upon reasonable grounds therefor may detain and question such person in a reasonable manner for the purpose of ascertaining whether the person is guilty of theft such questioning of a person by a merchant a merchants employee or peace or police officer does not render the merchant merchants employee or peace officer civilly or criminally liable for slander false arrest false imprisonment malicious prosecution or unlawful detention   evidence of value for purposes of this chapter when theft occurs from a store evidence of the retail value of the thing involved shall be prima facie evidence of the value of the thing involved evidence offered to prove the retail value may include but shall not be limited to fixed labels and tags signs shelf tags and notices   use of photographs videotapes or films of property photographs videotapes or films of and upon conviction thereof shall be punished by a fine in an amount that does not exceed the maximum fine provided for in    complicity  complicity a a person is legally accountable as principal for the behavior of another constituting a violation if with the intent to promote or facilitate the commission of the offense he or she aids abets advises or encourages the other person in planning or committing the offense b complicity is not a separate and distinct violation or offense under this it is not necessary to specifically charge complicity it is merely a theory by which a defendant becomes accountable for a violation or offense committed by another  lost abandoned or unclaimed personal property  application of chapter provisions this chapter shall apply to all personal property which shall be disposed of in accordance with the provisions of including any income or increment derived therefrom less any lawful charges that is held by or under the control of the city and which colorado unclaimed property act et seq crs 197 as amended b owner means a person or entity including a corporation partnership association governmental entity other than this city or a duly authorized legal representative or successor in interest of same which owns unclaimed property held by the city c city administrator shall mean the city administrator or designee thereof   procedure for notice and claims relative to and forfeiture of unclaimed property a prior to disposition of any unclaimed property having an estimated value of $5000 or more the city administrator shall send a written notice by certified mail return receipt requested to the last known address if any of any owner of unclaimed property the last known address of the owner shall be the last address of the owner as shown by the records of the municipal department or agency holding the property the notice shall include a description of the property the amount or estimated value of the property and when available the purpose for which the property was deposited or otherwise held the notice shall state where the owner may make inquiry of or claim the property the notice shall also state that if the owner fails to provide the city administrator with a written claim for the return of the property within 60 days of the date of the notice the property shall become the sole property of the city and any claim of the owner to such property shall be deemed forfeited b prior to disposition of any unclaimed property having an estimated value of less than $5000 or having no last known address of the owner the city administrator shall cause a notice to be published in a newspaper of general circulation in the city the notice shall include a description of the property the owner of the property the amount or estimated value of the property and when available the purpose for which the property was deposited or otherwise held the notice shall state where the owner may make inquiry of or claim the property the notice shall also state that if the owner fails to provide the city administrator with a written claim for the return of the property within sixty 60 days of the date of the publication of the notice the property shall become the sole property of the city and any claim of the owner to such property shall be deemed forfeited c if the city administrator receives no written claim within the above sixty 60 day claim period the property shall become the sole property of the city and any claim of the owner to such property shall be deemed forfeited d if the city administrator receives a written claim within the sixty 60 day claim period the city administrator shall evaluate the claim and give written notice to the claimant within ninety 90 days thereof that the claim has been accepted or denied in whole or in part the city administrator may investigate the validity of a claim and may request further supporting documentation from the claimant prior to disbursing or refusing to disburse the property e in the event that there is more than one claimant for the same property the city administrator may in the city administrators sole discretion resolve said claims or may resolve such claims by depositing the disputed property with the registry of the district court in an interpleader action f in the event that all claims filed are denied the property shall become the sole property of the city and any claim of the owner of such property shall be deemed forfeited g any legal action filed challenging a decision of the city administrator shall be filed pursuant to rule 106 of the colorado rules of civil procedure within thirty 30 days of such decision or shall be forever barred if any legal action is timely filed the property shall be disbursed by the city administrator pursuant to the order of the court having jurisdiction over such claim   disposition of unclaimed property the city administrator is authorized to establish and administer procedures for criminal trespass if such person 1 knowingly and unlawfully enters or remains in a dwelling of another or if such person enters any motor vehicle with intent to commit a crime therein  2 unlawfully enters or remains in or upon the premises of another which are enclosed in a manner designed to exclude intruders or are fenced  3 knowingly and unlawfully enters or remains in or upon the common areas of a hotel motel condominium or apartment building  4 knowingly and unlawfully enters or remains in a motor vehicle of another  5 unlawfully enters or remains in or upon premises of another designee is authorized to order the temporary closure of any public park skatepark basketball court tennis court or sections thereof to use by the general public with or without advance notice when it protect the recreational or other facilities within a public park from damage or destruction due to actual or anticipated circumstances or conditions  or 3 the closure is necessary to facilitate maintenance or repairs  or 4 the closure is warranted because the public park or facilities within a public park have been reserved for use by authorized persons teams or organized groups for athletic gorge park or within the boundaries of the city    guidelines and rules pertaining to skateparks a definitions unless otherwise required by context or usage words and terms used in this chapter shall be defined as follows 1 freestyle bicycle means a metal frame with two inline nonmetallic wheels on separate axles with no pegs wheels not more than twenty inches in diameter with handle bars and a seat designed for athletic stunts on flat or contoured surfaces of constructed of native soils asphalt or concrete 2 inline skate means a shoe with a set of nonmetallic wheels attached in a straight line commonly used for skating over a flat surface but not including a tricycle scooter or razor 3 riding surface means a flat or contoured hard surface or course within a park or a skatepark that is constructed of asphalt concrete or another durable material and which is available to users for inline skating skateboarding andor freestyle cycling where permitted 4 skateboard means a short board mounted on a small set of nonmetallic wheels which is used for coasting and often for performing athletic stunts 5 skatepark means any skatepark facility available for public use by skateboarders inline skaters and where not prohibited freestyle cyclists that is owned or operated by the city including but not limited to the skate park facility in mountain view park 6 user means any person who uses a skate park for skating or riding b guidelines the following guidelines shall apply in all skateparks 1 use of the skatepark shall be at the users own risk all users are cautioned to know their own skills and limitations 2 helmets knee elbow and wrist pads are strongly recommended at all times 3 users are strongly encouraged to know their abilities to use only those elements of the skatepark that are within their abilities to be courteous and respectful to others to take turns and to have fun 4 special events or organized group use shall be scheduled by obtaining a park use permit from the city administrator or his designee c rules the following rules shall apply in all skateparks 1 appropriate shoe wear must be worn sandals and bare feet are prohibited on riding surfaces at all times 2 the following items are prohibited and shall not be used on or near any riding surface within any skate park at any time a bicycles with wheels over twenty inches in diameter  b bicycles with pegs or similar devices protruding from the wheels of the bicycle  c scooters  d razors  e tricycles  f all forms of motorized equipment  g any other item or device prohibited by signage posted at the skatepark 3 adding to or modifying skatepark features with makeshift items such as jumps or ramps is prohibited as is skating or riding on any park structure outside of the riding surfaces that is not intended or suitable for such use 4 no food drinks or tobacco products are permitted on riding surfaces 5 the use of profanity in a skatepark is prohibited 6 no glass containers are permitted anywhere in a skatepark 7 no illegal drugs or alcohol beverages are permitted anywhere in a skatepark 8 no metal shovels sand or salt may be used on any riding surface 9 destroying or defacing public property is prohibited tagging or placing stickers or graffiti upon any skatepark surface or structure is defacing public property and is illegal 10 spectators and pets are not allowed on riding surfaces 11 no person shall ride a bicycle or skate in a skatepark in such a manner as to indicate a wanton and willful disregard for the safety of another person or of property willful and wanton conduct consists of an affirmative act purposefully committed which the person who committed the act must have realized as dangerous done heedlessly and recklessly without regard to consequences or the rights and safety of others 12 no unauthorized person shall enter use remain in or refuse to leave a skatepark when the skatepark is not open for public use see  d revocation of privilege to use skatepark 1 use of the skatepark shall be a privilege and the city acting director of parks or his or her designee shall have the right and authority to revoke either temporarily or permanently the privilege of any person to use a skatepark if that person does not obey or otherwise adhere to the guidelines and rules contained in subsections b and c of this section or if that person violates any other municipal ordinance or regulation pertaining to the use of a public park a skatepark or any facility therein all such revocations shall be documented in writing and shall identify the person whose privilege has been revoked by name and address when known and clearly state the date when the period of revocation will end 2 the revocation of a persons privilege to use the facilities of a skatepark shall be in addition to any penalty that may be imposed by the municipal court upon the conviction of such person for a violation of any rule set forth or otherwise provided for in this section 3 a persons physical presence at or use of a skatepark or any facility therein when such persons privilege to use such skatepark or facility has been revoked pursuant to paragraph 1 of this d shall be unlawful and upon such persons conviction of such violation shall be punishable as provided for in   unlawful activities designated a except as provided in of this section it is unlawful within any city park colloquial expressions hanging around and hanging out   juvenile loitering during nighttime hours a it shall be unlawful for any person under the age of eighteen 18 years to loiter or to aimlessly within a specified area   parental responsibility a it shall be unlawful for the parent guardian or other adult person having the care and custody of a juvenile under the age of eighteen 18 years to knowingly permit or allow such juvenile to loiter or to aimlessly drive or ride about at the places and within the time prohibited by this chapter the term knowingly includes knowledge which a parent should be reasonably expected to have concerning the whereabouts of a juvenile in that parent or guardians custody it shall be no defense that a parent guardian or other person having the care and custody of the juvenile was indifferent to the activities conduct or whereabouts of such juvenile   penalties a any person who violates any provision of this shall be punished by a fine in an amount otherwise permissible pursuant to crs  24335200 and the prescribed burning of fence lines or rows fields farm lands rangelands wildlands trash and debris open burning shall not include 1 fires in camp fire code adopted by the caon city area fire protection district as approved and ratified by resolution or ordinance of city council   authority for issuance and enforcement of official orders banning open burning and restricting access to hazardous fire areas a whenever the city administrator determines that conditions in and around the city are such that there is a high risk of fire in consultation with the fire chief and other local governmental entities with authority regarding fire restrictions the city administrator shall have the authority by written order to 1 to temporarily ban or otherwise restrict open burning  2 to ban or restrict the use of fireworks  and 3 to deny or restrict public access to any hazardous fire area within the jurisdiction of the city b copies of all such orders by the city administrator shall be promptly distributed to a newspaper of general circulation in the city posted on the citys official bulletin board at city hall and on the citys website notice of the city administrators order also may be given to the general public using other means of communication available to the city administrator c whenever the fire chief shall issue a written order banning or otherwise restricting open burning or denying or restricting public access to a hazardous fire area within the boundaries of the caon city area fire protection district and deliver a certified copy of such order to the office of the city administrator such order shall be enforceable within the jurisdiction of the city by the fire district copies of such orders by the fire chief shall be distributed and posted in the same manner and places as are provided for in subsection a of this section with respect to the written orders of the city administrator d in the event of a conflict between a provision of a written order of the city administrator and a provision of a written order of the fire chief the more stringent provision shall apply unless the written order of the city administrator provides otherwise   duration the city administrator or his or her designee is authorized to impose restrictions of a limited duration based on the nature and scope of the current conditions any such duration may be extended or modified by subsequent administrative order of the city administrator or his or her designee based on continuing adverse fire conditions persons physically present within the jurisdiction of the city shall be presumed to have actual knowledge of the terms of such official order   unlawful acts it shall be unlawful for any person to for formation of the districts and the issuance and sale of bonds therefor in the next succeeding months of december january february and march   prior code    preliminary surveydistrict formation a before ordering any public works or improvement and before creating any district therefor the council shall cause a preliminary survey to be made so as to determine the area to be affected thereby the kind of materials to be used in its construction the estimated cost thereof and the respective benefits to be derived from the improvement to the city at large and the property owners affected as a whole including publicly owned property and the proportion of the cost of the works or improvement to be borne by each b if the council determines that the public works or improvement should be made it shall by resolution 1 define the boundaries of the district  2 adopt details and specifications with respect to the materials to be used and the type of work to be done  3 determine generally the property to be assessed for the improvement  4 require the city engineer to make a map of the district showing the location of the works or improvements and a schedule showing the approximate amounts to be assessed against the several lots or parcels in the district  and 5 determine the number of installments and plan payment of the assessments and the rate of interest to be charged on all deferred payments   prior code    districtsnotice to property owners a the city clerk shall give notice to all property owners whose real property is proposed to be assessed for the property improvement by publication in a newspaper of general circulation in the city twice one week apart the last of which publications shall be made not less than ten days prior to the council meeting at which the ordinance creating the district and authorizing the improvement shall be considered on first reading of the following 1 the kind of improvements proposed to be made  2 the number of installments in which the assessment against the property are to be paid when such installments will be payable and the rate of interest to be paid on deferred installments  3 the boundaries of the district  4 the proposed method or methods of assessment and the estimated cost per linear front foot area or dollar of valuation as the case may be  5 the date when the ordinance creating the district and ordering the improvement will be considered by the council on first reading  6 that at the time of the first publication of the notice the map estimates and schedules of assessments with all proceedings in the matter are on file in the office of the city engineer and can be examined by any interested party during office hours at any time  7 that all objections to the proposed improvement or the proposed method of assessment will be heard by the council at the meeting at which such ordinance is to be considered or at some subsequent meeting thereof before final action upon such ordinance b the city clerk shall mail by ordinary mail postage prepaid to owners of all real property located in the proposed improvement district and whose real property may be assessed at their last known address determined by the city engineer from telephone directories city directories and records in the office of the assessor of fremont county between the first and second publications a copy of the notice being published   objectionsform and filing a all objections to any improvement or assessment made pursuant to the provisions of this chapter shall be in writing and subscribed by the party making the same or by his her or its attorney or agent duly authorized in writing to sign the same on behalf of the party making such objection or objections and the same shall be filed with the city clerk before the time set for hearing such objection b objection that the council did not have authority to order the improvement or that the assessment against any parcel exceeds the benefits thereto from the improvement shall be deemed waived and no right of action to enjoin the making of the improvement or the collection of assessments therefor shall exist unless such objections are first presented to the council at the time set for hearing the same any such right of action shall be barred unless commenced within thirty days after action of the council in overruling such objection or objections   objectionsadjustment at the time set in the notice for hearing objections the council shall hear the same and make such adjustments as it may deem proper and just and it shall adopt an ordinance creating the district and ordering the improvements and if bonds are to be issued to pay for such improvements providing for the issuance of such bonds the ordinance shall also contain a recital of the disposition of all objections made as herein provided   council findings the finding by the council in any ordinance resolution or proceeding that any improvement was ordered after notice duly given and hearing held shall be conclusive of such facts in every court or tribunal   irregular lotsassessments based upon area a where a district contains lots or parcels that are of irregular dimensions the relative areas of the several benefited lots or parcels shall be the basis for calculating assessments to be levied against such lots and parcels with respect to the cost of street alley and sidewalk improvements when all such parcels or lots contain approximately the same acreage the assessments may be apportioned equally among all such lots or parcels without regard to frontage abutting the improvements in such cases equal apportionment of costs shall be the preferred method of assessment b in all cases where a method of assessment other than the front footage method is adopted by city council the method of assessment so adopted shall be presumed valid unless it is established by an owner of property within the district who has filed a timely objection by clear and convincing evidence that the application of such method of assessing the objectors property would be inequitable and place upon the property of such objector an assessment which is unnecessarily disproportionate when compared to the amounts to be assessed against other properties within the district and that the benefits to the objectors property accruing as a result of the improvements are substantially less than the benefits accruing to other lots and parcels within the district that win be assessed similar amounts under the method of assessment adopted by city council   assessment methods proposed in the petition a notwithstanding the provisions of if the owners of a majority of the lots and parcels in a proposed improvement district representing greater than fifty percent of the total area of the district excluding rightsofway and other publicly held property within the district clearly specify in their petition a preferred method of assessment city council will adopt such method of assessment unless it finds that the adoption of such method would be inequitable with respect to the amount of assessments to be levied under such method against property within the proposed district owned by persons who did not join in the petition b where a preferred method of assessment is proposed in a petition meeting the requirements of of this council shall presume that the method of assessment so proposed is equitable as to all lots and parcels within the district if no objection to the adoption of such method is filed by any owner of property to be included within the district prior to the adoption of the ordinance creating the district   apportionment of costs a except as otherwise provided in of this section the cost of the construction or improvement of streets alleys sidewalks curbs and gutters shall be assessed against the property benefited thereby according to the linear measurement of the portion of the property abutting the street alley or thoroughfare so constructed or improved  provided that the cost of improving intersections may be assessed on land without regard to lot or land lines on a frontage zone or other equitable basis and the cost of improving the street or alley abutting the longer of the two corner lot lines may be assessed to a depth substantially equal to the length of such line in accordance with the benefits as the same may be determined by the council b the costs of the construction or improvement of storm sewers and sanitary sewers shall be assessed against the property benefited according to area c the cost of the acquisition of lands for vehicular parking lots the cost of improving lands for such parking lots the cost of the improvement of any street or sidewalk by the installation or construction of any parking parkway and the cost of the ornamentation of any parking parkway street or sidewalk and the planting care or removal of grass trees shrubbery plants lights benches trash receptacles along in on or over streets boulevards sidewalks parkways and places may be assessed against the property benefited according to area when so determined by the council d the cost of all other public works or improvements not above mentioned shall be assessed against the real property benefited ad valorem provided that tile cost of any public works or improvement may be made payable out of revenues derived therefrom when authorized by the qualified electors as provided in the charter   improvement bonds not needed when when the total estimated cost of any construction or improvement exclusive of collection inspection and incidental costs and interest to be added shall not exceed five thousand dollars according to the finding in any ordinance authorizing the improvement the council may order payment of the cost of such construction or improvement without issuance of bonds out of any funds held by it when not prohibited by the charter of caon city  provided that all revenues derived from interest upon and collection of the special assessments levied against real property of such improvements as well as the principal of such assessments and all tax sale certificates and property obtained from such assessments shall belong to and be returned to the fund out of which such advance was made  and provided further that if any funds so used shall be needed before the same shall be repaid out of such special assessments the council may use other funds held by the city to reimburse the fund out of which the advance was made and all certificates and property obtained and all revenues payable thereafter shall belong to the fund from which the money was last obtained   assessment objectionsnotice of hearing a when the total cost of any construction or improvement is definitely ascertainable the council shall determine the total cost for administration and interest on bonds issued or to be issued up to the time of payment of the first installment of the assessment the amount of such total cost payable by the city and the amount to be assessed on each lot or parcel in the district including lots or parcels publicly owned  and the city clerk shall publish in a newspaper of general circulation in the city a notice containing such determination and advising all interested parties of the date for hearing of objections to such determination and assessments such notice shall be published twice one week apart and the last of such publications shall not be less than ten days prior to the date set for hearing such objections b the city clerk shall mail by ordinary mail postage prepaid to all real property owners at their last known address determined by the city engineer from telephone directories city directories and records in the office of the county assessor between the first and second publications a copy of the notice being published c the administrative fee provided for herein may be reduced by the council to reflect the value of improvements in a proposed improvement district which could not otherwise be required by the municipality and which are determined by the council to be necessary or beneficial to the public in general   prior code    filing of petitions a petition is any written instrument filed under this chapter except petitions initiated for improvement districts pursuant to but specifically including any response to notice given under the terms of public hearings required by  shall be subject to the following provisions a any letter written memorandum or other written communication shall be considered as a petition or an objection each petition shall set forth 1 the name of the property owners  2 the street address of the real property and shall be addressed to the city council and filed with the clerk of the city  3 a specific statement or indication of whether the signer is in favor of or opposed to the formation of the district  4 the front footage of the property owned b the first petition and only the first petition received by the city from any property owner shall be considered by the council c property owners who have filed petitions need not be present at any public hearing to be held by the council covering matters addressed by their petitions d all petitions relating to matters covered by or included within a bill for an ordinance which will be considered by the council shall be filed with the city clerk at least three and onehalf working days eightyfour hours before the council meeting at which the ordinance bill will be considered on first reading e oral arguments at any public hearing of the council by any property owner may be dispensed with by the mayor in the event the owner has filed a petition   prior code    adjustment of assessments objections to the apportionment and assessment of costs shall be heard and determined by the council at the time stated in the notice or at some adjourned date  and upon such hearing the council shall make such adjustments of such apportionment and assessments as it may deem just and equitable and adopt an ordinance apportioning and assessing such costs against the several lots or parcels in the district   local assessment roll the director of finance shall prepare a local assessment roll in book form showing in suitable columns each piece of land assessed the total amount of assessment the amount of each installment of principal and interest if in pursuance of this chapter the same shall be payable in installments and the date when each installment will become due with suitable columns for use in case of payment of the whole amount or of any installment or penalty   assessmentspayment requirements payments may be made to the director of finance at any time within thirty days after the final passage of the assessing ordinance at the expiration of such thirtyday period the director of finance shall deliver the local assessment roll to the county treasurer therein showing all payments made thereon with the date of each payment certified by the director of finance under the seal of the city with his warrant for the collection of the same the county treasurer shall receipt for the same and all such rolls shall be numbered for convenient reference   assessmentsdue date a all special assessments for local improvements shall be due and payable within thirty days after the final adoption of the assessing ordinance without demand  provided that all such assessment may at the election of the owner be paid in installments with interest as provided in this chapter b the director of finance shall cause notice of assessments due for improvements constructed to be published within ten days after the adoption of the assessing ordinance on final reading in one issue of the caon city daily record and likewise shall mail the notice by ordinary mail postage prepaid to the owner of each parcel of real estate being assessed within the same period of time   assessmentslien provisions a all assessments made in pursuance of this chapter together with all interest thereon and penalties for default in payment thereof and all costs in collecting the same shall from the date of the final passage of the assessing ordinance constitute a perpetual lien and shall have priority over all other liens except general state county city town or school taxes b as to any subdivision of any land assessed pursuant to this chapter the assessment shall in each case be a lien upon all of the subdivisions in proportion to their respective areas c no delays mistakes errors or irregularities in any act or proceeding authorized by this chapter shall prejudice or invalidate any final assessment but the same may be remedied by subsequent amending acts or proceeding as the case may require and when so remedied the same shall take effect as of the date of the original act or proceeding d if in any court of competent jurisdiction any final assessment made in pursuance of this chapter is set aside then the ordering authority may upon notice as required in the making of an original assessment make a new assessment in accordance with the provisions of this chapter   installment paymentsregulations failure to pay the whole assessment within the period of thirty days shall be conclusively considered and held to be an election on the part of all persons interested whether under disability or otherwise to pay in such installments all persons so electing to pay in installments shall be conclusively held and considered as consenting to such improvements and such election shall be conclusively held and considered as a waiver of any right to question the power or jurisdiction of the city to construct the improvements the quality of the work the regularity or sufficiency of the proceedings or the validity of the lien thereof   installment paymentsdue when in case of such election to pay in installments the assessments shall be payable in two or more equal annual installments of principal the first of which installments shall be payable as prescribed by the council in not more than five years and the last in not more than twenty years with interest in all cases on the unpaid principal the number of installments the period of payment and the rate of interest shall be determined by the council and set forth in the assessing ordinance   payment by part owner the owner of any divided or undivided interest in the property assessed may pay his share of any assessment upon producing evidence of the extent of his interest satisfactory to the treasurer having the roll in charge   installment paymentsdefault penalties a failure to pay any installment whether of principal or interest when due shall cause the whole of the unpaid principal to become due and collectible immediately and the whole amount of the unpaid principal and accrued interest shall thereafter draw interest at the rate of one percent per month or fraction of a month until the day of sale as hereinafter provided  but at any time prior to the day of sale the owner may pay the amount of all unpaid installments with interest at one percent per month or fraction of a month and all penalties accrued and shall thereupon be restored to the right thereafter to pay in installments in the same manner as if default had not been suffered b the owner of any property not in default as to any installment of paying may at any time pay the whole of the unpaid principal with the interest accruing to the maturity of the next installment of interest or principal c the period of any statute of limitations shall not commence to run against any such assessment until the last installment thereof shall become due and payable according to the assessing ordinance   defaultreal estate sale authorized when the county treasurer shall receive payment of all assessments appearing upon the assessment roll with interest and in case of default in the payment of any installment of principal or interest when due shall advertise and sell any and all property concerning which such default is suffered for the payment of the whole of the unpaid assessments thereon and such advertisements and sales shall be made at the same time or times in the same manner under all the same conditions and penalties and with the same effect as are provided by general law for sales of real estate in default of payment of general taxes   collections by county treasurer all collections made by the county treasurer upon such assessment roll in any calendar month shall be accounted for and paid over to the director of finance on or before the tenth day of the next succeeding calendar month with separate statements for all such collections for each improvement   special assessment bondsissuance conditions a for the purpose of paying all or such portion of the cost of any improvement constructed under the provisions of this chapter as may be time to pay the remaining bonds for the district and the interest due thereon the city shall pay if so provided in the ordinance authorizing the issuance of the bonds the bonds when due and the interest due thereon and reimburse itself by collecting the unpaid assessments due the district c such bonds may be used in payment of the cost of the improvement as specified herein  or the council upon advertisement once a week for three 3 consecutive weeks in a newspaper of general circulation in the city may sell sufficient of such bonds to pay such cost in cash for the best bid submitted in interest all such bonds shall be redeemed in their numerical order   property salescertificates of purchase a at any sale by the county treasurer of any property for the purpose of paying any special assessment for local improvements made under the provisions of this chapter the finance officer may purchase any such property without paying for the same in cash and shall receive certificates of purchase therefor in the name of the city the certificates shall be received and credited at their face value with all interest and penalties accrued on account of the assessments in pursuance of which the sale was made the certificates may thereafter be sold by the finance officer at their face value with all interest and penalties accrued and by him assigned to the purchaser in the name of the city and the proceeds credited to the fund created by ordinance for the payment of such assessments respectively b such assignments shall be without recourse and the sale and assignments shall operate as a lien in favor of the purchaser and assignee as is provided by law in the case of sale of real estate in default of payment of general taxes  work and encroachment on city property  purpose this chapter provides procedures and regulations for the placement of structures and infrastructure construction excavation encroachments and work activities within or upon any public rightofway or other city property and is intended to protect the integrity of city property as well as the health safety and welfare of the public to achieve these purposes it is necessary to require permits for temporary or continuing uses of the public rightsofway and to establish permit procedures   definitions clear zone means the total roadside border area starting at the edge of the traveled way available for safe use by errant vehicles more generally defined as an unobstructed relatively flat area beyond the edge of the traveled way that allows a driver to stop safely or regain control of a vehicle that leaves the traveled way this area may consist of a shoulder a recoverable slope a nonrecoverable slope andor a clear runout area the desired minimum width is dependent upon traffic volumes and speeds and on the roadside geometry the clear zone width is at the discretion of the city engineer based on characteristics of the roadway and traffic but is typically two 2 feet from the back of the curb when present or ten 10 feet from the edge of the pavement when no curb is present horizontal landscaping means landscaping that is generally low to the ground and includes shrubs or plants shorter than thirty 30 inches sod seed and other living ground cover rock stone brick concrete asphalt or other like materials for nonliving ground cover rock stone or brick shall not exceed a nominal size of six 6 inches or be stacked or placed to a height greater than eight 8 inches includes irrigation pipe and irrigation appurtenances incidental encroachment means an encroachment which is incidental to the general publics use of the rightofway accompanying or consequential to a land owners use of their property but not a major part of their use and typical in nature throughout the city minor encroachment means an encroachment which does not impede vehicle or pedestrian traffic affect the rights of the city or other third parties in the encroachment area or is temporary in nature major encroachment means any encroachment which is not a minor or incidental encroachment public property means any and all property rightofway or other real or personal property owned or controlled by a public entity rightofway means any public street way place alley sidewalk utility easement owned or controlled by the city vertical landscaping means shrubs or plants taller than thirty 30 inches trees andor rocks stones and boulders exceeding a nominal size of six 6 inches or are stacked or placed to a height greater than eight 8 inches vision triangle means a triangular area on a lot at the intersection of two 2 streets or a street and a railroad or alley two 2 sides of which are lot lines measured from the corner intersection of the lot lines to a distance specified the third side of the triangle is a line across the corner of the lot joining the ends of the other two 2 sides where the lot lines and intersections have rounded corners the lot lines will be extended in a straight line to a point of intersection the vision clearance area shall contain no plantings walls structures or temporary or permanent obstructions exceeding two and onehalf 212 feet in height measured from the top of the curb or existing street grade the vision triangle shall be measured as provided in work means any labor performed on or any use or storage of equipment or materials including but not limited to construction of streets and all related appurtenances fixtures improvements sidewalks driveway openings bus shelters bus loading pads street lights and traffic signal devices it shall also mean construction maintenance or surveying that requires street lane closures or excavation  and repair of all underground structures such as pipes conduit ducts tunnels manholes vaults buried cable wire or any other similar structure located below surface and installation of overhead poles and wires or conductors used for any purpose   police powers the permittees rights hereunder are subject to the police powers of the city which include the power to adopt and enforce ordinances including amendments to this section necessary to the safety health and welfare of the public the permittee shall comply with all applicable laws and ordinances enacted or hereafter enacted by the city or any other legally constituted government unit having lawful jurisdiction over the subject matter hereof the city reserves the right to exercise its police powers notwithstanding anything in this section any permit issued hereunder any franchise or any other permit to the contrary any conflict between the provisions of this any franchise or any permit and any other present or future lawful exercise of the citys police powers shall be resolved in favor of the latter   incidental encroachmentsno permit or license agreement required incidental encroachments such as private horizontal landscaping or mailbox pillars driveway markers or trash receptacles with a capacity of ninetysix 96 gallons or less that are placed adjacent to the traveled lanes for removal on the scheduled date of pickup or any other object deemed by the city engineer to be incidental will not require a permit or license agreement   minor encroachmentslicense agreement required a no person shall construct or install any minor encroachment as determined by the city engineer such as fences private vertical landscaping or place any object temporarily in the public rightofway or public property without first obtaining a revocable license agreement approved by the city engineer b a fee for processing the revocable license agreement shall be set by city council resolution from time to time the revocable license agreement granted by the city is revocable at will by the city c application 1 an application for a minor encroachment shall be made on a form provided by the city upon submission of a complete application the city engineer shall forward copies of the applications to all appropriate departments for review and comment the application shall be accompanied by any applicable fee 2 upon approval by appropriate departments the city engineer shall prepare a revocable license agreement to be signed first by the applicant and final signature by the city engineer and the city administrator d standards for approval a revocable license agreement may be issued if the application meets the following criteria 1 the proposed encroachment does not create an obstruction to vehicle bicycle or pedestrian traffic in any way within existing or planned travel lanes andor pathways  2 the proposed encroachment does not infringe upon any easement rights held by the city other public agencies or utilities  3 the proposed encroachment does not obstruct the vision triangle at intersections of streets alleys or driveways as determined by the city engineer  4 the proposed encroachment will not be within the clear zone as determined by the city engineer based on the characteristics of the roadway and the traffic  5 the proposed encroachment does not create or contribute to a safety hazard  6 the proposed encroachment meets all standards and requirements of the city for location and improvements  7 the proposed encroachment will not have to be relocated in the next fortyeight 48 months due to a planned city project and as determined by the city engineer  and 8 city street trees approved and maintained by the city are not subject to the regulations in this chapter   major encroachmentspermit required a no person except the city or a person exempted by contract with the city shall undertake or permit to be undertaken any major encroachment involving the construction excavation work andor encroachment in the public rightofway or public property or operate and maintain any utility within the rightofway without first obtaining a permit from the city as set forth in this section each permit obtained along with associated documents shall be maintained on the job site and available for inspection upon request by the city except that pursuant to b no application or permit shall be required for the installation placement operation maintenance or replacement of micro wireless facilities that are suspended on cable operatorowned cables or lines that are strung between existing utility poles in compliance with the national safety subject to the exceptions listed therein b no permittee shall perform construction excavation work in or create an encroachment of an area larger or at a location different than that specified in the permit or permit application when construction excavation or work is commenced under an approved permit it becomes necessary to perform construction excavation or work in a larger or different area than originally requested under the application  the permittee shall notify the city immediately and within twentyfour 24 hours shall file a supplementary application for the additional construction excavation or work c permits for construction excavation or work shall not be transferable or assignable and work shall not be performed in any place other than that specified in the permit the applicant may subcontract the work to be performed under a permit provided that the holder of the permit as well as all subcontractors obtain a contractors license all insurance and financial security as required the permittee shall be and remain responsible for the performance of the work under the permit the physical construction of public improvements in new developments is the responsibility of the developer of the land ownership of those improvements remains with the developer of the land until acceptance by the city any person performing work on those improvements which are within a public way or on an area proposed for dedication as a public rightofway or utility easement but prior to acceptance by the city shall obtain a permit from the city and permission from the owner of the improvements and the proposed public way the permittee shall be financially responsible to the owner of the improvements to carry out all remedial work necessary to receive acceptance by the city of those improvements this financial obligation shall apply only to the work in the public way done by the permittee d any work or use of other city property other than rightsofway may be allowed by the city only if it is appropriate in the citys discretion or authorized by other city ordinances or regulations such use may be subjected to the provisions of this section in addition to any other terms and conditions required by the city e once the construction excavation or work has been completed and accepted by the city the permit shall expire unless an encroachment on public property remains in that case the permit shall continue until terminated or the encroachment is removed regardless of whether a permittee maintains a permit for a continuing encroachment any new work on the encroachment will require a new permit pursuant to this chapter f the installation of utility and communications facilities in rightsofway controlled by the colorado department of transportation shall nonetheless require the citys approval and compliance with applicable city ordinances   major encroachmentsapplication and conditions a an applicant for a permit for a major encroachment to allow construction excavation work or encroachment in the public rightofway under this section shall 1 file a written application made upon a form provided by the city which will include information necessary or convenient for the administration and enforcement of this section including but not limited to a statement that the applicant or its contractor is not delinquent in payments due to the city on prior work a fee payable upon application for processing the permit shall be pursuant to applicable rules regulations or specifications of the city or as set by city council resolution from time to time 2 attach copies of all permits or licenses including required insurance deposits bonds and warranties required to do the proposed work and to work in the public rightsofway if license or permits are required under the laws of the united states the state of colorado or the ordinance or regulations of the city 3 provide a satisfactory plan of work showing a the date of commencement and completion of the construction excavation or work  b a statement that such work will be performed in strict compliance with the requirements of this chapter and any other applicable provision of the   c protection of the subject property and adjacent properties when the city determines such protection is necessary  d protection of shade and ornamental plants and the restoration of turf when the city determines that damage may occur to such plants or turf  e a description and illustration or plan concerning the exact location depth length width surface area and nature of the construction excavation or work desired to be made together with the location of any underground utilities within a radius of ten 10 feet  f a satisfactory traffic control and erosion protection plan and permit in accordance with for the proposed construction excavation or work  and g list of all anticipated subcontractors b all permits issued for construction excavation or work may be granted only for the time to complete the work the applicant is required to review the permit prior to the expiration of the permit c permits shall not be issued to any person firm or corporation that is not licensed with the city in accordance with of this concerning construction excavation or work performed pursuant to an applicable and current franchise agreement with the city and the departments of the city d the permit shall be issued with terms and conditions as necessary and appropriate to implement this section and protect the public health safety and welfare including provisions for insurance indemnification a hold harmless and damage release for the city warranty and repair periods requirements for asbuilt plans and requirements to reimburse the city for any costs it incurs as a result of relying on inaccurate asbuilt drawings submitted to the city e permit fees upon completion of the work the applicant shall pay to the city a permit fee in an amount set pursuant to applicable rules regulations or specifications of the city or as set by city council resolution from time to time permit fees shall be waived for work done on behalf of the city pursuant to crs  3855108 and in exchange for permission to attach wireless service facilities to poles or structures in a rightofway owned by the city payment shall not be in excess of the amounts set forth in 47 usc  224 and 47 cfr   f indemnification any permittee who applies for a permit shall agree to indemnify and save harmless the city its authorized agents officers representatives and employees from and against any and all claims penalties liability or loss resulting from claims or court actions whether at law or in equity arising directly or indirectly out of any act or omission of the contractor his agents officers representatives or employees in constructing excavating or performing any work on any street alley sidewalk public rightofway or cityowned property g insurance the permittee shall post with the city engineer certification of general liability insurance covering such excavation work all insurance policies required in this section shall include complete operation coverage for a period of two 2 years from the date of application for each permit failure to maintain such insurance shall not relieve any applicant from liability such proof of insurance shall contain a clause that the city shall be notified by the insurer not less than thirty 30 days prior to any change in the policy or cancellation of such policy all liability insurance shall be approved by the city attorney as to form city council shall set the minimum coverages required by resolution all policies shall be applicable to all premises and operations the policy shall include coverage for bodily injury broad form property damage including completed operations personal injury including coverage for contractual and employee acts blanket contractual products and completed operations the policy shall contain a severability of interests provision and shall be endorsed to include the city and the citys officers employees and contractors as additional insureds no additional insured endorsement shall contain any exclusion for bodily injury or property damage arising from completed operations all liability insurance shall be approved by the city attorney as to form h performance bond 1 each permittee before being issued a permit shall provide the city at the permittees expense with a performance bond in a form and amount approved by the city the bond shall be in an amount equal to one hundred fifteen percent 115% of the citys estimate of the cost of restoration of the site of the construction excavation or work or five thousand dollars $500000 whichever is greater the cost of restoration shall include without limitation the removal of defective material recompaction of subgrade and base material and construction of surface improvements for permittees who typically have greater than ten 10 permits annually have the option of providing one bond annually in the amount of fifteen thousand dollars $1500000 2 the condition of such bond shall be that the permittee shall comply with all the ordinances and specifications of the city relating to excavating or working in any street alley sidewalk or other public rightofway or cityowned property 3 such bond shall be approved by the city engineer as to sufficiency and by the city attorney as to form and shall remain in full force and effect for a period of two 2 years from and after the date any excavation is made 4 in the event of a breach of any conviction  building numbering system  street names to be posted at the intersections of each street or avenue there shall be placed on at least one of the four 4 corners the names of the intersecting streets and the same shall be placed upon posts or other suitable places and shall be marked so as to be distinctly read   building numbering required it is made the duty of all owners or occupants of all buildings situated in the city to number them in the manner set out in this chapter and as may hereafter be provided by the city council by ordinance   decimal systemexisting numbers the decimal system of numbering houses is adopted but the numbers heretofore assigned to buildings except as hereinafter provided shall remain the numbers of such buildings respectively until otherwise changed by the city council by ordinance or resolution   one hundred numbers per block one hundred 100 numbers shall be assigned to each block beginning at first street in the west division of the city calling it 100 running easterly on each street until reaching the north and south street in each instance when new numbering shall be followed one hundred 100 numbers to each block eastward commencing at such north and south streets as zero   streets north and south from main street buildings on north and south streets or avenues shall be numbered north and south from main street as zero allowing one number to each twenty 20 feet for less space than twenty 20 feet onehalf numbers may be used   even and odd numbers in numbering only full blocks shall be given hundred numbers and across all undivided tracts intervening between portions laid out into blocks the lines of streets shall be considered to cross in regular continuance of streets in additions and on all streets or avenues running north and south even numbers shall be placed on the east side  and on all streets and avenues running east and west the even numbers shall be placed on the south side all odd numbers alternating in each case shall be placed on the opposite side of the street thereon   numbers per lot size one hundred 100 numbers are allotted for each block but two 2 numbers shall be used for each frontage of fortyfour 44 feet and one number for each twentyfive 25 foot lot except in the business portion of the city where onehalf numbers may be used   assignment of numbers the city administrator shall appoint some suitable person to assign each house its proper number   size and placement of figures each of the figures of every number shall not be less than two and onehalf 25 inches in length and so marked as to be distinctly and easily read such numbers shall be placed in a conspicuous place on or above the front door of the building to which the same are attached   failure to number buildingpenalty any person being the owner or occupant of any building who after being notified of the proper number for the building shall for thirty 30 days thereafter decline or refuse to number any building owned or occupied by him or her in conformity with the provisions of this chapter is guilty of a misdemeanor  prohibitions with respect to the parking and storage of commercial vehicles recreational vehicles and trailers on residential streets within the city limits of the city of caon city   definitions as used in this chapter a commercial vehicle means and includes any vehicle used to transport cargo or passengers for profit hire or otherwise to further the purposes of a business or commercial enterprise  any vehicle described in 1a crs  or any vehicle described in c of this including boat trailers snowmobile and motorcycle trailers horse trailers and similarly used vehicles d recreational vehicle means and includes any recreational vehicle described in c of this   and shoulder or other similar designation g store stored or storing means the leaving of a vehicle unattended h trailer as used in this chapter means and includes any camper trailer semitrailer trailer described in of this section   parking and storage of commercial and recreational vehicles and trailers on residential streets prohibited a except as permitted in of this section no commercial vehicle
