hereby incorporated punishment for such violations shall be as provided for in c1 of the caon city municipal  historic preservation  title this chapter shall be known and cited as the caon city historic preservation   purpose and declaration of policy a it is hereby declared as a matter of public policy that the protection preservation and enhancement of sites and structures of cultural historical and architectural significance located within the city is a public necessity and is required in the interest of the economic development civic pride and general welfare of the people of the city of caon city b the purpose of this chapter is to promote the public health safety and welfare  the designation preservation protection enhancement and perpetuation of those structures that reflect outstanding elements of the citys cultural social economic political architectural historic or other heritage  2 the enhancement of property values and the stabilization of historic neighborhoods and districts  3 the promotion of civic pride in the beauty and accomplishments of the past as represented in the citys landmarks and historic areas  4 the protection and enhancement of the citys attractiveness to tourists visitors home buyers employers residents potential investors and shoppers thereby supporting local business commerce and industry  5 the promotion of good urban design and the perpetuation of open space  and 6 the provision of educational opportunities to increase public appreciation of the citys unique heritage c the intent of this chapter is to create a method to draw a reasonable balance between private property rights and the public interest in preserving the citys unique heritage and historic character by ensuring that demolition or alteration of properties with historical significance shall be carefully considered   definitions unless specifically defined below words and phrases in this chapter shall be interpreted so as to give them the same meaning as they have in common usage and so as to give this chapter its most reasonable application 1 alteration means any proposed modification to a designated historic district site or structure which could have an effect on the character of the historic resource relative to the criteria by which it was designated examples of alterations for structures may include additions any exterior modifications including signage to be affixed to the faade 2 alteration certificate means a certificate issued by the historic preservation commission indicating its approval of plans for the alteration construction restoration removal or demolition of a designed historic resource 3 certificate of exemption means a certificate issued by the historic preservation commission authorizing alteration construction restoration removal or demolition of a structure even though an alteration certificate has previously been denied 4 commission means the caon city historic preservation commission 5 commissioner means a member of the historic preservation commission 6 compatible shall mean consistent with harmonious with andor enhances the mixture of complementary architectural styles either of the architecture of an individual structure or the character of the surrounding structures 7 construction means the act or process of adding an addition to an existing structure the remodeling of an existing structure or the erection of a new structure 8 contributing building means a building that is at least fifty 50 years old or older or is associated with significant people or events in the context of this chapter a contributing building is one of significance used for defining context and which retains a significant amount of its physical integrity and characterdefining features 9 demolition means any act or process that destroys in part or in whole a district structure or site 10 exterior architectural feature means the architectural style design general arrangement and components of the outer surfaces of a structure including but not limited to the color texture materials type size and style of all windows doors roofs lights siding signs and other fixtures appurtenant to the structure 11 historic district means a significant concentration linkage or continuity of historic resources united historically or aesthetically by plan or physical development 12 historic resource means a historic district site or structure 13 historic site means a location of a significant event historic occupation or activity where the location itself maintains historical cultural or architectural value and significance to the community regardless of the value of any existing building or structure 14 historic structure means anything constructed or erected the use of which requires permanent or near permanent location on or in the ground or attachment to something having permanent location on the ground 15 noncontributing building means a building regardless of age that has lost its integrity these buildings do retain value as residential or commercial properties but do not possess the significance or physical integrity necessary to be listed as a contributing building   historic preservation commission established a there is hereby created a historic preservation commission for the city of caon city which shall have principal responsibility for matters of historic preservation as set forth in this chapter b the commission shall consist of five 5 commissioners who shall be appointed by the city council c the commissioners shall serve three 3 year staggered terms from the date of appointment to stagger the initial terms of membership the original commission shall consist of one 1 member to serve one 1 year term  two 2 members to serve two 2 year terms  and two 2 members to serve three 3 year terms at least forty percent 40% of the commissioners shall be professional in preservationrelated disciplines such as architecture landscape architecture architectural history archaeology history planning american studies american civilization cultural geography or cultural anthropology if the required number of professional members cannot be found to serve on the commission this requirement may be waived until the next vacancy occurs at which time the city shall again diligently seek professional representation in the case of a lack of professional appointees the commission may with council approval be allowed to retain professional consultants to advise the commission as necessary to fulfill its duties d all commissioners shall serve without compensation except for such amounts determined appropriate by the city council to offset expenses incurred in performance of their duties e commissioners may be removed for cause by the city council f the commission shall by majority vote elect one 1 commissioner to serve as chairperson to preside over the meetings and one 1 commissioner to serve as vicechairperson the commissioners so designated shall serve in these capacities for terms of one 1 year and may serve successive terms g the commission shall by majority vote elect an individual to serve as secretary the secretary need not be a commissioner shall take minutes of each meeting shall be responsible for publication and distribution of copies of the minutes reports and decisions of the commission to its members and shall give notice as provided by law of all public meetings conducted by the commission the secretary shall also be responsible for transmitting minutes and any other required reporting to the state historic preservation office h the city council shall also appoint two 2 alternate commissioners who shall have the same qualifications provided for by this section   meetings of the commission a the commission shall hold at least one 1 regularly scheduled meeting per month unless there is no business to come before the commission or the commission is unable to obtain a quorum to conduct business meetings shall be scheduled by resolution of the commission at the beginning of each calendar year the commission chairperson may call a meeting at any time b the commission shall act only at meetings c no commissioner shall vote on any matter that may materially or apparently affect the property income or business interest of that commissioner d the chairperson and in his or her absence the vicechairperson may administer oaths and compel the attendance of witnesses e all meetings of the commission shall be open to the public minutes shall be kept of all commission proceedings and sent to the state historic preservation office upon approval f a quorum for the commission shall consist of a majority of the regular membership excluding vacant seats a quorum is necessary for the commission to hold a public hearing or take official action a tie vote shall be deemed a denial of the motion or recommended action   powers and duties of the commission a to adopt its own procedural regulations b to conduct an ongoing survey to identify properties structures and areas in the city that are culturally architecturally andor historically significant to the city county state or nation c to keep a register of all districts sites and structures that have been locally designated as historic resources d to hold public hearings for reviewing applications for construction alteration restoration removal or demolition affecting proposed or designated historic districts sites and structures e to issue or deny alteration certificates and certificates of exemption for historic districts sites and structures f to adopt criteria and specific design standards or guidelines for review of historic resources and for review of proposals to alter restore demolish or move designated historic structures andor resources g to review structures resources and areas nominated for designation as a historic districts sites or structures and recommend that the city council make such designations by ordinance h to act as a resources for owners within designated historic districts and for owners of designated historic sites and structures on physical and financial aspects of preservation renovation restoration and rehabilitation including the process for nomination to the national register of historic places i to develop and assist in public education programs including but not limited to walking tours brochures lectures and conferences j to advise the city council on matters related to preserving the overall historic character of the city k to actively pursue financial assistance for historic preservation programs l to oversee and maintain on behalf of the city any historic property or full or partial interest in historic real property including easements that the city may own or accept as a gift or otherwise upon authorization and approval of the city council m to testify before all boards and commissions including the planning commission and the board of adjustment on any matter affecting a designated historic resource n to undertake any other action or activity necessary or appropriate to the implementation of its powers and duties or to the implementation of the purpose of this chapter o to prepare an annual report of the commissions activities for the state historic preservation office including at a minimum the number and types of cases reviewed and their dispositions new historic designations made progress on historic survey activities education activities and credentials of new commission members and staff if any   designation of historic district site or structure pursuant to the procedures set forth herein the city council may by ordinance a designate in the city as having cultural architectural or historical significance a historic structure an integrated group of structures and features on a single lot as a historic site or a larger grouping as a historic district b each such designating ordinance shall include a description of the historic characteristics of the district site or structure that justify its designation and a description of the particular features that should be preserved and shall include a legal description of the location and boundaries of the district site or structure c the designating ordinance may also indicate alterations that would have a significant impact upon or be potentially detrimental to the historic district site or structure d any historic designation of a district site or structure shall be in furtherance of and in conformance with the purposes and criteria set forth in this chapter e the property included within a designated district or site and designated historic structures shall be subject to the controls and standards set forth in this chapter and shall be eligible for such incentive programs as may be developed by the commission   procedure for designating historic district site or structure a nomination for designations shall be made to the commission on forms prepared by it and may be submitted by the commission the property owner or a citizen nominations for historic district site or structure must contain the approval of all current owners of record b upon nomination the commission shall contact the owners of record of all affected property or properties either in person or in writing outlining the reasons and effects of designation as a historic resource c once an application is complete the commission shall hold a public hearing on the nomination no more than sixty 60 days after the filing of a complete application as determined by the city manager or designee notice of the date time place and general subject matter of such hearing shall be published at least once in a newspaper of general circulation in the city not less than fifteen 15 days prior to the hearing in addition the commission shall post notice of the hearing on the nominated property structures or cites at least fifteen 15 days prior to the hearing finally written notice shall be sent by first class mail at least fifteen 15 days prior to the hearing to all affected property owners as determined from county records whose property would be included in the proposed historic designation d at the public hearing the commission shall hear evidence in support of or against the proposed designation and review the application for conformance with the established criteria for designation and with the purposes of this section e within thirty 30 days after the public hearing the commission shall recommend approval modification and approval or denial of the application for designation if recommended for approval the commission shall refer the application to the city council f within thirty 30 days after the referral from the commission the city council shall hold a public hearing on the proposed designation notice of the date time place and general subject matter of such hearing shall be published at least once in a newspaper of general circulation in the city not less than fifteen 15 days prior to the hearing in addition notice of the hearing shall be posted on the nominated property structures or areas at least fifteen 15 days prior to the hearing g at the public hearing the city council shall hear evidence in support of or against the proposed designation and review the application for conformance with the established criteria for designation and with the purposes of this section h within thirty 30 days of the public hearing the city council shall approve modify and approve or deny the proposed designation if the designation is approved the city council shall adopt a designating ordinance i within fifteen 15 days of the effective date of the designating ordinance the commission shall record with the county clerk and recorder a certified copy of the ordinance j if the commission determines that a proposed district site or structure does not meet the criteria for designation as a historic resource any of the affected property owners may appeal the commissions decision by filing a written appeal with the city council within thirty 30 days of the commissions decision   criteria for designation the commission shall consider the following criteria when reviewing nominations for designation a designation as an historic resource all resources proposed for historic designation shall be at least fifty 50 years old and shall possess architectural social geographic or environmental importance by meeting one 1 or more of the following criteria 1 exemplifies specific elements of an architectural style or period 2 is an example of the work of an architect or builder who is recognized for his or her national statewide regional or local expertise 3 demonstrates superior craftsmanship or high artistic value 4 represents an innovation in construction materials or design 5 represents a style particularly associated with the area 6 represents a built environment of a group of people in an era of history 7 represents a pattern or grouping of elements representing at least one criteria in this  has undergone a significant historic remodel 9 is the site of a historic event that had an effect upon society 10 exemplifies cultural political economic or social heritage in the community 11 represents an association with a notable person 12 is identified with historical personages or groups or which represents important events in national state or local history 13 enhances a sense of identity with the community 14 is an established and familiar natural setting or visual feature in the community b historic districts in addition to complying with above districts proposed for historic designation shall demonstrate a pattern of physical elements or social activities significance is determined by applying the criteria of this chapter to patterns and unifying elements 1 historic district designation will not be considered unless the application contains written approval of all property owners within the proposed historic district boundaries 2 properties that do not contribute to the significance of the proposed historic district may be included within the boundaries if the noncontributing buildings do not noticeably detract from the proposed historic districts sense of time place and historic development noncontributing elements will be evaluated for their magnitude of impact by considering their size scale design location or information potential c any historic landmark listed on the national register of historic places or the colorado state register of historic properties shall be deemed to qualify for local designation under this chapter  however such landmarks shall not be locally designated until an application for designation is filed and processed pursuant to this chapter   alteration certificate required a no persons shall cause or permit to be caused on or in a designated historic resource any construction alteration restoration removal or demolition without first obtaining an alteration certificate for the proposed work from the commission b the building division shall not issue a building permit for work on or in a designated historic resource until an alteration certificate or exemption certificate has been obtained by the property owner c an application for any construction alteration or demolition on or in a historic resource must be filed with the commission on a form provided by the commission d the commission shall consider the application and determine whether the proposal preserves the criteria for which the resource was designated or adds to the architectural cultural or historical significance of the resource the commission shall make its review pursuant to the procedures in e criteria to review alteration certificate application in reviewing a proposed alteration the commission shall consider the project in terms such as design finish material scale mass and height and if the alteration is compatible with the historic designation the commission shall use the following criteria to determine compatibility of a proposed alteration 1 the effect upon the general historical and architectural character of the district site or structure  2 the architectural style arrangement texture and material used on the existing and proposed structures and their relation and compatibility with other structures  3 the size of the structure its setbacks its site location and the appropriateness thereof when compared to existing structures and the site  4 the compatibility of accessory structures and fences with the main structure on the site and with other structures  5 the effects of the proposed work in creating changing destroying or otherwise impacting the exterior architectural features of the resource upon which such work is done  6 the condition of existing improvements and whether they are a hazard to public health and safety  7 the effects of the proposed work upon the protection enhancement perpetuation and use of the resource  8 the ability to comply with the secretary of the interiors standards for rehabilitation and guidelines for rehabilitating historic buildings a section of the secretary of the interiors standards for the treatment of historic properties of the department of the interior regulations 36 cfr  as may be amended from time to time  and 9 guidance provided by the national park service historic preservation briefs as the same may exist from time to time f historic districtsadditional criteria for contributing buildings in addition to the considerations set forth in above in reviewing a proposed alteration of a contributing building within a historic district the commission shall consider the following 1 the effect upon the general historic and architectural character of the building  2 the architectural style arrangement texture and material used on the existing and proposed buildings and their relation and compatibility with other historic landmarks including state and national designations  3 the effects of the proposed work in creating changing destroying or otherwise affecting the exterior architectural features of the building upon which such work is done  4 the effects of the proposed work upon the protection enhancement and perpetuation of the building  5 the condition of existing improvements and whether they are a hazard to public health and safety  6 the compatibility of accessory buildings structures and fences with the main building and with other historic landmarks  and 7 substantial compliance with the secretary of the interior standards as they apply to building exteriors only except those relating to paint color which shall not apply g historic districtsadditional criteria for noncontributing buildings in addition to the considerations set forth in above in reviewing a proposed alteration of a noncontributing building within a historic district the commission shall consider the following 1 noncontributing buildings should be compatible with contributing building  2 noncontributing buildings should not attempt to mimic or duplicate the historic features of contributing buildings  and 3 contemporary designs that creatively draw upon the important characteristics of a historic district are favored h if an alteration certificate is approved the designated resource will retain its historic designation i if an alteration certificate is denied any of the affected property owners may appeal the commissions decision by filing a written appeal with the city council within thirty 30 days of the commissions decision   certificate of exemption a if an alteration certification is denied or the affected property owners cannot comply with the recommendations from the commission for changes necessary for the issuance of an alteration certificate the owner or owners may make application for a certificate of exemption b application for a certificate of exemption shall be made on a form prepared by the commission the commission shall schedule a public hearing and provide notice as outlined in c the commission shall consider the following factors in determining whether to issue a certificate of exemption 1 the cost of the proposed construction alteration restoration or demolition and the estimated additional cost if any of complying with the recommendations of the commission for changes necessary for the issuance of an alteration certificate  2 a report from a licensed engineer or architect concerning the structural soundness of the historic resource and their suitability for rehabilitation  3 the estimated market value of the historic resource in its current condition after completion of the proposed work after any changes in the proposed work recommended by the commission and in the case of a demolition after renovation of the historic resource for other uses  4 the amount paid for the historic resource the date of purchase the party from whom the historic resource was purchased and the relationship if any between the applicant and the person from whom the historic resource was purchased  5 if the historic resource is incomeproducing the annual gross income and itemized operating and maintenance expenses from the historic resource for the previous two 2 years  6 the remaining balance on any mortgage or other financing secured by the historic resource  7 any appraisals of the historic resources value obtained by the applicant or other affected property owners within the previous two 2 years  8 any listing of the historic resource or a portion thereof for sale or rent price asked and offers received if any during the previous two 2 years  9 the real estate taxes on the historic resource for the previous two 2 years  and 10 any other information that may be relevant for the commissions consideration of the application d the commission shall review the evidence and testimony presented and issue written findings and conclusions within fortyfive 45 days of receipt of the application if a certificate of exemption is granted the applicant may proceed with the construction alteration restoration removal or demolition without further delay imposed by this chapter e if a certificate of exemption is denied the affected property owners may appeal the commissions decision by filing a written appeal with the city council within thirty 30 days of the commissions decision   revocation enforcement and penalties a if a structure or special feature of a designated historic department for the purpose of the waterworks as the same are at present completed in sections most convenient for the proper keeping of such records under the direction of the water superintendent there shall be prepared and maintained additional records that indicate as nearly as practicable from the information in such records and notes the locations of all active water mains and all points where such mains are believed to have been tapped   permit authority a possession of permits required by subsections b or c or both b and c of this section shall be the authority for a contractor to perform work specified in this chapter within the citys rightsofway all work undertaken pursuant to either such permit shall be done with reasonable dispatch and in accordance with applicable city standards all contractors applying for either such required permit must be licensed with the city and bonded to perform work within the citys rightsofway b no person other than employees of the department shall perform any excavation work required or authorized in this chapter within the citys rightsofway without first having obtained a valid excavation permit pursuant to of this no person shall connect any service line to a water main without first having obtained a valid permit provided for in such permit shall be in addition to an excavation permit if the person making the connection also performs associated excavation work within a city rightofway   connecting to mainspermit and procedures a an application shall be made to the engineers office for a permit to tap the mains of the department if granted such permit shall be signed by the engineer or designee and shall contain the following information 1 the name of the person for whose benefit such permit is granted  2 the size of the tapstop for discharging the water from the main to the service line and the point as nearly as possible at which the tap is to be made  3 the address and legal description of the property to be served  4 the contemplated use of the water to be delivered connection authorized in the permit  and 5 any other information reasonably requested by the water superintendent or engineer on a written application form or in written instructions to applicants b a record of all such permits shall be kept in a book maintained for that purpose at city hall which record shall set forth the substance of every such permit no water user served by the department shall be entitled to more water than is necessary for the use stated on the permit no water user shall use water for a purpose that is different than that stated on the permit when no use is specified on the permit domestic household uses shall be the presumed use unless and until the water superintendent and the water user agree otherwise in writing c the burden of proving the issuance of a permit with respect to any property shall be on the owner of such property such proof must be made prior to the departments authorizing any service connection no person shall be entitled to a water service connection unless proof of such permit is presented to the department andor is clearly evidenced in the departments permanent records d all service connections or taps on all mains served by the department shall be made by department personnel or by persons specifically engaged by the department to perform such work connections will be made only after the mains have been inspected tested approved and accepted by the department any excavation necessary for tapping shall be completed prior to the arrival of department personnel the property owner or other applicant shall provide at no cost to the department the tapping saddle or tapping sleeve and corporation stop necessary to make the service connection e each service connection may be used to serve only the property identified in the water tap application and permit permitted taps may not be moved from one property to another  provided however that the subdivision of a lot or parcel shall not result in the loss of water service to one of the resulting lots created subdivision of a lot or parcel if such subdivided lot or parcel had been receiving or was entitled to receive water service pursuant to valid permit andor water service connection prior to the subdivision of such lot or parcel   connecting to mainssupervision and enforcement other work is performed in accordance with the ordinances regulations requirements standards policies and administrative directives of the city no developer property owner or contractor acting on behalf of any property owner shall deny department personnel access to places were water service connections are to be made or have been made the denial of such access shall be grounds for the denial andor dwelling units are prohibited except when expressly permitted by specific provisions of this chapter or by a written contract permitted under this chapter and approved by city council b no water service line that is less than threefourths of one inch in diameter shall be installed or used to transport potable water from a water main to the shutoff or meter of any water user larger service type k soft copper shall be used for service lines sized threefourths inch inch materials meeting the specification of the water superintendent such as ductile iron pipe or plastic pipe may be used specifications f service lines shall be the same size as the tap installed on the water main between the main and the meter additionally the meter shall be the same size as the tap   service linesshutoff requirements a a shutoff of the same size as the service line shall be installed at the property line unless a pit meter with stop has been installed at the property line the shutoff shall be equipped with a curb box and lid in accordance with city of caon city standard construction specifications b any vault meter pit or area containing a meter greater than one inch in diameter shall be kept accessible and in good working condition by the property owner any such box or meter pit that is not properly taken care of by the property owner shall be cleaned repaired or relocated by the water department if not promptly cleaned repaired or relocated by the property owners qualified contractor following notice from the department such costs shall be added to the water users utility billing statement and shall be payable in full on or before the due date for the payment of water service charges appearing on such billing statement unless other payment arrangements are approved in writing by the director of finance c the department shall not be liable to any property owner tenant or other party in possession of any property to which water is conducted for the failure on the part of the department and its personnel to readily find a shutoff box or lid in order to shut off the water to any property   service linesmaintenance duties a the owner or occupant of any property to which water is conducted shall keep all customerside service lines and related fixtures tight and in good repair so as to prevent the waste of water when aware of any leak the water user shall forthwith eliminate the waste of water by repairing or replacing all defective water lines andor fixtures that are causing or contributing to the cause of the leak b the water user shall request the department to turn off water service when repairs to the water service lines or any other component are necessary on the customer side of the meter and defer any work thereon until the water service has been turned off by department personnel who shall respond to such requests with reasonable dispatch c each water user shall be responsible for the repair of all leaks emanating from any segment of the customerside service line water service is received if any leak is of a serious nature andor has not been repaired within a reasonable period of time as determined by the water superintendent the customerside service line may be disconnected by the department at either the shutoff meter or main and such users water service shall be discontinued until the customerside service line has been repaired by the water user to the reasonable satisfaction of the water superintendent   location of water facilities a department water mains pumps pump houses and storage tanks may be extended enlarged or constructed within the service area of the department as defined from time to time by the water superintendent  provided that all such improvements are accomplished in conformance with the city of caon city standard construction specifications and authorized by the water superintendent or engineer all such facilities may be located anywhere within the departments service area at sites designated or approved by the water superintendent or engineer b no transmission main water main or other water service facility shall be extended enlarged installed or constructed at any location other than upon real property owned or controlled by the city or the department or within the rightofway of a public street or other public way a perpetual dedicated utility easement or a perpetual easement otherwise created or existing for the benefit of the department the preferred location of all water mains shall be within public streets or within platted private streets open to public use c except as otherwise might be provided in this chapter or in a separate agreement authorized or approved by formal action of city council the costs of all water system improvements requested by any water user applicant for water service developer or property owner shall be borne by the person requesting the water service making such improvements necessary   sizing of water mains a sizing of water mains shall be determined by the engineer or water superintendent subject to the following requirements 1 except for permanent culdesacs of less than five hundred 500 feet in length the minimum size of any new water main within the service area of the water department shall be eight 8 inches in diameter 2 in streets that have a permanent culdesac less than five hundred 500 feet in length the engineer or water superintendent may authorize a water main that is six 6 inches in diameter 3 in locations where it is determined by the engineer or the water superintendent that a water main must be larger than eight 8 inches in diameter the water main shall be of such size as the engineer or water superintendent shall specify 4 all determinations made pursuant to subsections 2 and 3 of this subsection shall take into account among other relevant factors the water departments most recent water main master plan copies of which shall be kept in the engineers office and in the offices of the department of public works such water main master plan by necessity is and will remain a fluid and flexible plan the requirements of which may change from time to time and at any time depending upon existing and anticipated demands upon the water service system and the location condition age sizing and functionality of existing water system facilities and components 5 all water main and appurtenance designs shall be approved by the engineer or water superintendent prior to commencement of installation such design shall conform to the city of caon city standard construction specifications and all installations shall conform to the approved design 6 the water main sizing requirements set forth in this subsection shall apply in all new subdivisions andor developments within the departments service area unless the engineer or water superintendent approves a water service development plan providing for different sizing of one or more water mains in which case the approved plans will control b if pursuant to subsections 3 and 4 of the engineer or water superintendent requires a water main larger than eight 8 inches fronting or abutting any or all sides of the real property to be served the applicant shall pay for and install such larger water mains upon the satisfactory completion of the installation any water main larger than eight 8 inches in diameter the water department will promptly reimburse to the person that installed such water main a sum which represents the excess in the cost of materials for such water main over what would have been the cost of materials had only an eight 8 inch water main been installed if the greater size of the water mains is due to a water system need rather than a project need of the person who installed such mains as determined by the engineer or water superintendent the applicant will not be entitled to and will not be reimbursed for any excess labor or other costs that were incurred in connection with the installation of the larger water main   cashinlieu of installation payments if the department requires an undersized water main fronting or abutting an applicants property to be replaced at the applicants expense in accordance with the provisions of this chapter the applicant may in lieu of making the installation and with the consent of the water superintendent and engineer pay to the water department an amount equal to the cost of the required water main installation the amount of any such cashinlieuofinstallation payment shall be determined by the engineer who shall establish and periodically review and adjust when changing costs indicate a need for adjustment a costperlinearfoot standard to be applied uniformly for purposes of calculating cashinlieu of installation payment chapter   water line rebates and agreements a the water superintendent may enter into contracts on behalf of the department whereby a portion of the cost of the installation of a water main extension or enlargement required by the department and paid for by the other party to the contract may be recovered on an equitable prorata basis from water users who subsequently tap such water main as extended or enlarged such contracts shall be known as water main rebate agreements b no water main rebate agreement shall be prepared or executed by the water superintendent unless such agreement is requested in a written application the form of which shall be provided by the water superintendent filed by the person or persons entitled to request such agreement such application must be filed no later than six 6 months from the date the subject water main extension or enlargement was accepted by the city as determined by the records of the engineer such date shall be the acceptance date c no water main rebate agreement shall be executed by the water superintendent until the engineer has received as built documents and has received and reviewed complete and accurate records and supporting documentation showing the actual cost of the water main extension or enlargement that will be the subject matter of the agreement such records and documentation must be received within six 6 months of the acceptance date any application for a water main rebate agreement which is not supported by such as built drawings records and other supporting documentation shall be an incomplete application an incomplete application shall be void and of no force and effect d no water main rebate agreement shall have a term which ends later than on the tenth 10th anniversary date of the acceptance date provided for in of this section unless a longer term is approved by council following the end of such term neither party to the rebate agreement shall have further rights or obligations under such agreement e every water main rebate agreement executed by the water superintendent shall be recorded at the expense of the other party to such agreement such party shall pay all recording costs prior to the recording of the agreement with the fremont county clerk and recorder unless recorded no such agreement shall be binding upon the department f no water main rebate agreement shall impose upon the department a duty to collect refund amounts with respect to any new connection to the enlarged or extended water main from the person making such new connection unless the application for the agreement was received by the department prior to the time such new connection was authorized by the department g every water main rebate agreement shall provide that the departments obligations under such agreement shall be limited to the departments using its best efforts to collect prorated refund amounts from those who connect to the extended or enlarged water main after the written application for the agreement has been received by the department and prior to the termination date provided for in the agreement h every water main rebate agreement also shall provide that the department shall not be liable to any other party to the agreement for any failure by the department to have collected the appropriate refund amount from a person connecting to the extended or enlarged water main except that the department may be liable with respect to such refund amount if it is proven by clear and convincing evidence in a legal proceeding that such refund was not collected or was not distributed after collection as a result of gross negligence or fraud i each other party to any such agreement must provide to the department prior to preparation and execution of the water main rebate agreement their current address and give the department written notice of any change of address occurring during the term of the rebate agreement funds collected by the department pursuant to a water main rebate agreement that are not claimed by the party entitled to receive such funds within one year of the departments sending notice of the receipt of such funds to such party at the last known address of such party shall be forfeited to and become the exclusive property of the department the last known address of any such party shall be the address stated in the rebate agreement or the last address provided to the department by the written notice of change of address required under this subsection j all calculations of refunds to be collected by the department and distributed to the other party to a water main rebate agreement shall be made by the engineer under a formula approved by the water superintendent such formula shall take into account the actual cost of extending or enlarging the water main as determined by the engineer calculations of refund amounts shall be based upon the relationship between the frontage of the property receiving new water service and the total frontage of all properties abutting the extended or enlarged water main on both sides thereof k whenever the department extends or enlarges a water main or participates financially in a water main extension or enlargement by paying a portion of the cost of materials or otherwise the department shall be entitled to recover its actual costs of such extension or enlargement from the owners of adjacent property that is connected to such enlarged or extended main within ten 10 years following the completion of the extension or enlargement of such water main the department shall maintain for public reference a complete list of all water main improvements with respect to which rebates to the department will be required pursuant to the provisions of this subsection including the applicable cost per linear foot incurred by the department to pay for each such improvement the amount of any rebate that becomes payable pursuant to this subsection will be calculated in the same manner as rebates under water main rebate agreements are calculated l rebate amounts collectible by or otherwise owing to the department pursuant to any of the provisions of this section must be paid in full prior to the making of any new water service connections for the benefit of any person connecting to an extended or enlarged water main with respect to which such provisions apply   fire hydrant use restrictions and exceptions a except as provided in of this section no water shall be drawn or used from any fire hydrant connected to the water system of the department whether such fire hydrant is located inside or outside of the corporate limits of the city b exceptions to general prohibition water may be drawn from fire hydrants 1 by employees and agents of the caon city area fire protection district or any other fire protection district or department responsible for extinguishing fires in the vicinity of the fire hydrant only for purposes of extinguishing fires or for other purposes permitted by contract between the city and the district or department 2 by employees and authorized agents of the city when used for any municipal purpose 3 by persons under contract with the city for the performance of public improvement contracts let by the city provided that such water so drawn is used exclusively for purposes authorized or otherwise contemplated in the contract with the city and further provided that all such water so used is measured by a meter issued by the department it shall be unlawful for any person under contract with the city for the performance of a public improvements contract to use water drawn from a fire hydrant for any project or other purpose that is not provided for or otherwise contemplated in the contract 4 by other governmental or quasigovernmental entities such as fremont county or the fremont county sanitation district pursuant to the terms of any agreement between the city and such other entity 5 by licensed contractors to whom the department has issued a meter to measure such contractors water usage for use in connection with any private project or projects c licensed contractors who are authorized to draw water from fire hydrants pursuant to b5 shall be subject to the following conditions and requirements 1 unless otherwise authorized by the water superintendent the meter issued by the department shall be used at all times when water is drawn from a hydrant 2 a deposit in an amount set by the water superintendent must be paid in advance 3 no refund of such deposit shall be made until all sums associated with the use of the meter and the water drawn meter have been paid in full no refund shall be due sooner than thirty 30 days following the contractors return of the meter 4 a meter rental fee in an amount determined by the water superintendent may be charged 5 the contractor shall pay or reimburse the department for any and all costs incurred to repair any fire hydrant damaged by the contractor or its employees or agents and with respect to any damage to the meter itself including replacement costs if the meter is returned in a damaged or broken condition 6 the contractor shall pay at the applicable rate for all water from all hydrants that is drawn meter or otherwise used by the contractor 7 no water drawn by any contractor pursuant to this subparagraph shall be resold or be used to supply drinking water to any person 8 any contractor drawing or attempting to draw water pursuant to this subsection shall immediately report to the water superintendent or designee any damage to or malfunction of any fire hydrant encountered by such contractor 9 each contractor entitled to draw water pursuant to this shall keep an accurate written log with respect to such contractors use or attempts to use fire hydrants pursuant to this such log shall identify each such fire hydrant used by location date and time of usage and approximate water usage copies of such logs shall be delivered to the department no less often than monthly and in any event at any time the meter issued by the department is returned to the department 10 the water superintendent may require the contractor to sign a written agreement making reference to the contractors obligations under this subsection prior to authorizing such contactor to draw water from any fire hydrant d the water superintendent may implement and enforce such rules regulations and policies that are deemed by him or her to be necessary to regulate usage of water drawn by contractors and others pursuant to the provisions of this voluntary administrative remedy a whenever it shall appear to the city administrator that a violation of this chapter has occurred the matter may be referred to the city attorneys office with instructions that a determination be made as to whether proceedings should be instigated against the apparent violator or violators in municipal court and such proceedings may thereafter be instigated or the city administrator may attempt to resolve the issue administratively b at his or her discretion the city administrator is hereby authorized but not obligated to cause the apparent violator or violators to be contacted and offered the opportunity to pay an administrative fee and where applicable those charges referred to in subsections g and h of this section to resolve issues created by the apparent violation c any person to whom an offer authorized under is made shall have not less than ten 10 or more than twenty 20 days within which to accept or reject the offer unless this period is extended by the city administrator the offer shall be deemed accepted only if the violator signs a form prescribed by the city administrator which shall contain the violators admission to the offense which shall be described in the form by reference to municipal code section and approximate date of occurrence and tenders payment of the appropriate administrative fee for the violation admitted and if applicable the charges under or h of this section at least two 2 counterpart originals of the form shall be executed by the violator and by the city administrator or designee with one counterpart original to be furnished to the violator and a second counterpart original being held in the records of the city for a period of not less than seven 7 years from its execution any violator who wishes to attach to the citys copy of the admission form his her or its written explanation of the events giving rise to the violation admitted by such person may do so and such explanation shall be attached to the counterpart original retained by the city d no admission once made shall be withdrawn and no administrative fee or other charge payable under this section once paid shall be refunded e the administrative fee payable under such circumstances shall be an amount equal to the minimum fine that would be imposed by the municipal court upon a conviction of the violator of the offense admitted on the written form after the city administrator has determined whether the violation is a first second third or subsequent offense municipal court fines are as set forth in f in cases where more than one person appears to have committed the same violation such as when a plumber makes an illegal connection at the request of a water user the admission of one such apparent violator shall not be grounds for excusing the apparent violation of the other in such cases the offer permitted under may be communicated to the several apparent violators and may be accepted by some or all of them an admission by one such violator shall not preclude the prosecution and possible conviction of the other in municipal court g in cases where the property or facilities of the water department were damaged or destroyed during the commission or as a direct result of the commission of a violation of this chapter the city administrator may impose as an additional condition of the offer an additional charge in an amount equal to the water departments cost of repairing or replacing the damaged or destroyed property or facilities including the costs of labor and materials when such a condition is contained in the offer no admission will be accepted unless accompanied by the violators payment of the administrative fee and the charge imposed under this subsection h in cases where water department water was received but not paid for by the violator or made available to and received by another efforts of or due to the acquiescence of the violator such as when illegal or unauthorized connections are made in front of a violators water meter either because its usage was not metered or because applicable minimum or other usage charges on metered water were not billed the city administrator may impose as an additional condition of the offer an additional charge in an amount equal to the city administrators best reasonable estimate of the maximum revenues not paid to or received by the water department as a result of the alleged violation of this alleged violator who wishes to make an admission pursuant to must upon request by the city administrator provide reasonable cooperation by providing dates and other details important to the city administrators estimate under this subparagraph when such a condition is contained in the offer no admission will be accepted unless accompanied by the violators payment of the administrative fee and the charges imposed under this subsection i no alleged violator shall be obligated to accept any offer made pursuant to this section no person who does make an admission pursuant to this section and pays the administrative fee and other applicable charges referred to in this section shall be prosecuted in municipal court with respect to the admitted violation no refusal to accept any offer made by the city administrator shall be offered as evidence in any municipal court proceeding that might be brought against any alleged violator j no admission made pursuant to this section shall constitute a conviction for purposes of the penalties that must be imposed by the municipal court for second third or subsequent convictions of violators under this chapter but such prior admissions and prior municipal court convictions occurring within the seven 7 year period ending on the date of the violation admitted pursuant to this section shall be considered by the city administrator in determining the amount of the administrative fee payable under this section k the city administrator if such referral was not previously made shall refer to the city attorneys office for possible prosecution a report with respect to all apparent violations of this chapter with respect to which the offer authorized under was communicated and rejected l the city administrator is hereby authorized to adopt a schedule of administrative fees rules regulations and policies consistent with the provisions of this chapter for purposes of implementing this section  backflow prevention and crossconnections  definitions unless the context specifically indicates otherwise the meanings of terms used in this chapter shall be as follows a approved backflow prevention assembly means a backflow prevention assembly described in foundation for crossconnection control and hydraulic researchs fccc & hr most current list of approved backflow prevention assemblies or american society of sanitary engineers asse b backflow means the undesirable reversal of the direction of flow of water or mixtures of water and other liquids gases or other substances into the distribution pipes of the potable water supply from any sources caused by backpressure andor backsiphonage c backflow preventer means a device designed to prevent backflow created by backpressure or backsiphonage d backpressure means backflow caused by a pump elevated tank boiler or means that could create an elevated pressure within the nonpotable system greater than the supply pressure e backsiphonage means the flow of water or other liquids mixtures or substances into the distribution pipes of a potable water supply system from any source other than its intended source caused by negative or subatmospheric pressure in the potable water supply system f certified crossconnection control technician means a person who is certified in accordance with the provisions of of the colorado primary drinking water regulations g colorado crossconnection control manual means the most recent edition of a manual that has been published by the state addressing crossconnection control practices which will be used as a guidance document for the utility in implementing a crossconnection control program as outlined in h containment means the installation of an approved backflow prevention device or method on the water service lines so that water delivered to the service line cannot return to the city potable water distribution system due to any backpressure andor backsiphonage condition which might arise i contamination means an impairment of the quality of the potable water by sewage industrial fluids or waste liquids compounds or other materials to a degree which creates an actual hazard to the public health or spread of disease j crossconnection means any physical arrangement whereby a public water supply is connected directly or indirectly with any other water supply system sewer drain conduit pool storage reservoir plumbing fixture or other device which contains or may contain contaminated water sewage or other waste or liquid of unknown or unsafe quality which may be capable of imparting contamination to the public water supply as a result of backflow bypass arrangements jumper connections removable sections swivel or changeover devices fourway valve connections and other temporary or permanent devices or because of which backflow could occur are considered to be crossconnections k director means the director of public works of the city or if none a city water department employee designated by the city administrator in writing l hazard degree of degree of hazard means an evaluation of the potential risk to public health and the adverse effect of the hazard upon the potable water system m isolation means a backflow device installed on a branch of the internal plumbing to protect the customers water system n nonpotable water means water that is not safe for human consumption or that is of questionable quality o pollution means the presence of any foreign substance organic inorganic radiological or biological in the water that may degrade the water quality so as to constitute a hazard or impair its usefulness p potable water means water free from impurities in amounts sufficient to cause disease or harmful physiological effects the bacteriological chemical and radiological quality shall conform with state of colorado department of public health and environment primary drinking water regulations q utility means the city of caon city water department a water activity enterprise of the city of caon city r water service connection means the terminal end of the citys service connection from the public potable water system  ie where the city loses jurisdiction and sanitary control over the water at its point of delivery to the customers stop box or shutoff valve or meter whichever comes first from the utility water main if a meter is installed at the end of the service connection then the service connection shall mean the downstream end of the meter there shall be no unprotected takeoffs from the service line ahead of any meter or backflow prevention device located at the point of delivery to the customers water system service connection shall also include any water service connection from a fire hydrant and all other temporary or emergency water service connections from the public potable water system   requirements a implementation and enforcement of a crossconnection control program the director is vested with the authority and responsibility for implementing and enforcing an effective crossconnection control program in accordance with the provisions of this chapter b backflow preventers required at all service connections an approved backflow preventer shall be required at each and every service connection to a water service customers premises for the safety and protection of the city water supply system and water users connected to that system c the director shall have the authority to specify the type of backflow preventer to be installed at each service connection the directors decision with respect to the type of backflow preventer that will be required in any specific situation shall be based upon the degree of hazard posed by the facility connected or to be connected to the city water supply system the degree of hazard shall be determined on a casebycase basis depending upon the circumstances of each particular case in making determinations as to the degree of hazard and the type of device required the director shall rely upon the latest published edition of the colorado crossconnection control manual for guidance and may rely upon other generally accepted authorities including but not limited to the official publications of the american society of sanitary engineering the director shall give notice in writing to the customer to install such an approved backflow prevention device at each service connection to the customers premises d inspections and testing procedures the director has the authority to inspect any system owned and maintained by a utility customer to determine the extent and degree of hazard e the utility shall notify the utility customer at any premises where containment backflow preventers are installed to have certified inspections and operational tests made upon installation of the containment device and at least once per year thereafter the director may require certified tests at more frequent intervals if the director deems the potential hazard to be great enough these inspections and tests shall be performed by a certified crossconnection control technician f the director reserves the right to inspect or require the inspection of installed backflow preventers at any time to ensure the devices are in proper working order the devices shall be repaired overhauled or replaced whenever they are found to be defective these inspections tests and repairs shall be at the owners expense records of such tests repairs and overhaul including materials and parts changed shall be filed with the director within ten 10 days of such activities the utility shall keep and maintain such records in accordance with the requirements of applicable law 1 containment devices will be tested annually according to the colorado revised statutes and colorado department of public health and environment primary drinking water regulations 2 if such devices are allowed by the director as an acceptable alternative to total containment isolation devices used to isolate and lower the overall degree of hazard for a property will be tested on a schedule determined by the director 3 isolation devices used on lawn irrigation sprinkler devices will be tested upon installation repair or relocation but in any event no less often than once annually g policy 1 no water service connection to any premises shall be installed or maintained unless the water supply is protected as required by colorado revised statutes the regulations of the colorado department of public health and environment and by this chapter 2 water service to any premises shall be denied or discontinued as the case may be by the utility if a a backflow preventer required by this chapter is not installed within the time period specified by the director  b an approved backflow preventer has been removed or bypassed  or c an unprotected crossconnection exists on the premises  d an approved backflow preventer is not maintained 3 whenever service is denied or discontinued it shall not be provided or restored until the condition or defect identified in subparagraph c2 has been corrected 4 the customers system shall be open for inspection at all reasonable times to authorized representatives of the director to determine whether crossconnections or other structural or sanitary hazards including violations of this chapter exist 5 when as a result of an inspection a condition involving a violation of this chapter resulting in a health or sanitary hazard is determined to exist or a utility customer fails to properly test repair or otherwise maintain a backflow preventer as required by this chapter the director shall have the option of immediate discontinuance of water service to the premises until the condition has been corrected or the director may specify a date for compliance after which time the director may discontinue service until the customer has corrected the condition h installations of backflow prevention devices 1 backflow preventers shall be installed immediately downstream of the water service customers water meter whether the meter is a pit set or an interior set in all cases backflow preventers must be installed before the first branch line leading off the service line 2 with the directors approval a backflow preventer may be installed to isolate a hazard and lower the degree of hazard for containment such approval shall not be given unless the director is convinced that the use of the isolation device will pose no threat to the public water supply system 3 all backflow preventers shall be located and installed according to the manufacturers specifications and in accordance with this chapter and the city of caon city design standards and construction specifications or the colorado crossconnection control manual the director shall review and approve all plans as to the type location and installation of backflow prevention devices 4 utility customers shall be responsible for the design installation and maintenance of properly sized and located drains and drain systems whenever the type of backflow preventer specified or approved by the director requires a drain 5 plans shall not be modified relative to the type location or installation of any backflow preventer approved by the director without the directors prior knowledge and written authorization 6 if the location or removal of the backflow preventer results in the meter becoming contaminated the customer shall bear the cost of decontamination i device testing equipment 1 the acceptability of any testing gauge or apparatus shall be determined by the utility 2 any testing gauge apparatus or scientific instrument utilized for the testing of backflow prevention devices shall be checked for accuracy at least yearly and be in calibration the director may require certificates or other proof of calibration for such items to be filed with the utility 3 at a minimum all test gauges must meet asse1064 standards for gauges 4 all certified crossconnection technicians who perform work in the city shall file copies of their licenses with the utility upon the directors request j listings identifying approved backflow prevention devices any approved backflow prevention assembly required in this chapter shall be of a model and size approved by the director and listed in the fccc & hrs list of approved backflow prevention assemblies andor american society of sanitary engineers asse series 5000   compliance procedures a installation of required devices 1 upon completion of inspection of the premises or in the case of new construction on review of the construction plans the director shall notify the owner in writing of the type of device that will be required at each service connection within the owners facility 2 the owner shall at its expense purchase and install the device and any necessary plumbing or construction such plumbing and construction shall meet all provisions of the colorado crossconnection control manual and the city of caon city design standards and construction specifications and must be inspected and approved by the utility the device including any device installed prior to the effective date of the ordinance codified in this chapter shall be the property of the owner b compliance required 1 the utility will take necessary action to ensure compliance with the colorado department of health primary drinking water regulations 5 ccr 10031 and more specifically thereof and the colorado revised statues as amended 2 the owner of the premises is required to permit entry to the premises for inspection testing and maintenance purposes at reasonable times failure to permit entry to the premises will result in the premises being regarded as a high hazard and a reducedpressureprinciple device will be required to protect the citys water supply system 3 the owner is required to provide all necessary plumbing and construction needed for the installation of the device failure to provide such required plumbing and construction will result in action being taken as provided for in   appeals a any decision of the director regarding the type of backflow preventer required with respect to any water service connection may be appealed to the city administrator provided that a notice of appeal is filed in the office of the city administrator not later than twenty 20 days following the date upon which the directors written notice specifying the type of device is delivered to the property owner or its agent b the notice of appeal shall identify the property owner by name mailing address telephone number and email address if any and include the address of the owners facility such notice shall 1 identify the directors decision that is being appealed  2 identify the type of backflow preventer that the owner believes should be installed at the owners facility  and 3 include the owners reasons for preferring such backflow preventer instead of the backflow preventer designated by the director with or without written documentation supporting the owners position c within ten 10 days following the filing of the notice of appeal the city administrator by written notice specifying the date time and place of the hearing shall schedule a hearing such hearing shall be conducted no later than thirty 30 days following the date upon which the notice of appeal was filed unless the owner and the city administrator both agree to a later hearing date at the hearing the owner may present testimony evidence and arguments in support of the owners position and the director may present testimony evidence and arguments in support of the directors decision d the directors decision shall be affirmed unless the city administrator finds that the directors decision was arbitrary or capricious or that such decision violates applicable federal state or local law the city administrators decision shall be rendered in writing no later than ten 10 days following the hearing and shall be final e the paramount issue with respect to any appeal will be whether the type of backflow preventer authorized will adequately protect the public water supply system f before deciding any appeal the city administrator shall consider 1 whether the backflow preventer specified by the director is necessary to adequately protect the citys water supply system  2 whether the backflow preventer preferred by the owner would adequately protect the citys water supply system  3 whether the use of the backflow preventer preferred by the owner when compared to the backflow preventer designated by the director is likely to result in a material decrease in the level of protection to the public water supply system g in cases where an existing structure is being remodeled or reconstructed or where a change in the use of an existing structure will or may create a greater degree of hazard to the public water supply system than previously existed the city administrator may consider 1 differences in the cost of devices and backflow prevention assemblies when comparing the type of backflow preventer specified by the director to the type of backflow preventer preferred by the owner  2 differences in the cost of installing and maintaining the two 2 types of backflow preventers being compared  3 other significant cost differences or practical difficulties associated with the use installation andor maintenance of the backflow preventers being compared  4 other relevant life safety or health concerns raised by the director or the owner   jurisdictional issues and conflicts in the event the provisions of this chapter are in conflict with the requirements of any plumbing code or regulation applicable in the city the provisions of this chapter shall apply to the extent necessary to resolve the conflict and shall be binding upon all plumbing officials performing official duties within the city   violationpenalties a the director shall notify the owner or authorized agent of the owner of the building or premises of a violation of this chapter the director shall set a specific time for the owner to have the violation removed or corrected if the owner fails to correct the violation in the specified time the director may if in his or her judgment an imminent health hazard exists suspend water service to the building or premises additional fines or penalties may also be invoked following suspension of service b violations of this may be prosecuted in municipal court and upon conviction thereof a violator may be fined in an amount that does not exceed the maximum fine provided for in    water rates and fees  codealert this topic has been affected by to view amendments service a persons seeking new water service connections to the water departments system may apply for a water tap permit on forms provided by the water department no permanent water service connection will be authorized unless the application for the water tap permit has been perfected in accordance with the requirements set forth in this section 1 the applicant must file a complete and accurate application in accordance with the requirements of such information as is requested by the city engineer inaccurate andor incomplete applications will be rejected 2 the applicant must tender payment of the full tap fee as determined with respect to if applicable any impact fee provided for pursuant to or any water line rebate required under  the applicant or someone on the applicants behalf must complete according to applicable city standards and specifications and to the reasonable satisfaction of the city engineer all infrastructure improvements necessary to make the desired connection and provide water service to the applicants property 4 the property to be served generally must be a legally created lot or parcel the recording of a subdivision plat creating the lot or parcel to be served will be a necessary prerequisite to water service in most instances 5 if the property to be served is outside city boundaries the owner of such property will be required to execute and perform a water service contract approved by city council and meeting the requirements of in addition to the requirements set forth in this section all prerequisites to the provision of water service that are set forth in such water service contract must be performed before water service connections to the owners property will be permitted by the water department   applications for water tap permitscontents and process applicants requesting water service must file a completed application for water service with the engineer the application shall be made on such form as may be furnished or prescribed by the engineer such application at a minimum shall contain the applicants name address and telephone number  the legal description and street address if any of the real property to be served  a statement describing all structures if any existing on the property at the time the application is submitted  a statement advising whether the property is within or outside of the corporate limits of the city at the time the application is submitted  a statement describing all structures if any the applicant intends to construct or have constructed on the property described in the application and the estimated completion date of each such structure such application also may request other information deemed necessary by the engineer relative to the operation of the water departments system and the keeping of records with respect to such system if an incomplete or materially inaccurate application is filed this requirement will not have been met by the applicant and the applicant shall be so notified by the engineer no application shall be deemed filed until it has been determined to be complete and accurate by the engineer   tap fees a general provisions except
